1880 
1881 class wishart_gen(multi_rv_generic):
1882     r"""A Wishart random variable. 
1883  
1884     The `df` keyword specifies the degrees of freedom. The `scale` keyword 
1885     specifies the scale matrix, which must be symmetric and positive definite. 
1886     In this context, the scale matrix is often interpreted in terms of a 
1887     multivariate normal precision matrix (the inverse of the covariance 
1888     matrix). These arguments must satisfy the relationship 
1889     ``df > scale.ndim - 1``, but see notes on using the `rvs` method with 
1890     ``df < scale.ndim``. 
1891  
1892     Methods 
1893     ------- 
1894     pdf(x, df, scale) 
1895         Probability density function. 
1896     logpdf(x, df, scale) 
1897         Log of the probability density function. 
1898     rvs(df, scale, size=1, random_state=None) 
1899         Draw random samples from a Wishart distribution. 
1900     entropy() 
1901         Compute the differential entropy of the Wishart distribution. 
1902  
1903     Parameters 
1904     ---------- 
1905     %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
1906     %(_doc_random_state)s 
1907  
1908     Raises 
1909     ------ 
1910     scipy.linalg.LinAlgError 
1911         If the scale matrix `scale` is not positive definite. 
1912  
1913     See Also 
1914     -------- 
1915     invwishart, chi2 
1916  
1917     Notes 
1918     ----- 
1919     %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
1920  
1921     The scale matrix `scale` must be a symmetric positive definite 
1922     matrix. Singular matrices, including the symmetric positive semi-definite 
1923     case, are not supported. Symmetry is not checked; only the lower triangular 
1924     portion is used. 
1925  
1926     The Wishart distribution is often denoted 
1927  
1928     .. math:: 
1929  
1930         W_p(\nu, \Sigma) 
1931  
1932     where :math:`\nu` is the degrees of freedom and :math:`\Sigma` is the 
1933     :math:`p \times p` scale matrix. 
1934  
1935     The probability density function for `wishart` has support over positive 
1936     definite matrices :math:`S`; if :math:`S \sim W_p(\nu, \Sigma)`, then 
1937     its PDF is given by: 
1938  
1939     .. math:: 
1940  
1941         f(S) = \frac{|S|^{\frac{\nu - p - 1}{2}}}{2^{ \frac{\nu p}{2} } 
1942                |\Sigma|^\frac{\nu}{2} \Gamma_p \left ( \frac{\nu}{2} \right )} 
1943                \exp\left( -tr(\Sigma^{-1} S) / 2 \right) 
1944  
1945     If :math:`S \sim W_p(\nu, \Sigma)` (Wishart) then 
1946     :math:`S^{-1} \sim W_p^{-1}(\nu, \Sigma^{-1})` (inverse Wishart). 
1947  
1948     If the scale matrix is 1-dimensional and equal to one, then the Wishart 
1949     distribution :math:`W_1(\nu, 1)` collapses to the :math:`\chi^2(\nu)` 
1950     distribution. 
1951  
1952     The algorithm [2]_ implemented by the `rvs` method may 
1953     produce numerically singular matrices with :math:`p - 1 < \nu < p`; the 
1954     user may wish to check for this condition and generate replacement samples 
1955     as necessary. 
1956  
1957  
1958     .. versionadded:: 0.16.0 
1959  
1960     References 
1961     ---------- 
1962     .. [1] M.L. Eaton, "Multivariate Statistics: A Vector Space Approach", 
1963            Wiley, 1983. 
1964     .. [2] W.B. Smith and R.R. Hocking, "Algorithm AS 53: Wishart Variate 
1965            Generator", Applied Statistics, vol. 21, pp. 341-345, 1972. 
1966  
1967     Examples 
1968     -------- 
1969     >>> import numpy as np 
1970     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
1971     >>> from scipy.stats import wishart, chi2 
1972     >>> x = np.linspace(1e-5, 8, 100) 
1973     >>> w = wishart.pdf(x, df=3, scale=1); w[:5] 
1974     array([ 0.00126156,  0.10892176,  0.14793434,  0.17400548,  0.1929669 ]) 
1975     >>> c = chi2.pdf(x, 3); c[:5] 
1976     array([ 0.00126156,  0.10892176,  0.14793434,  0.17400548,  0.1929669 ]) 
1977     >>> plt.plot(x, w) 
1978     >>> plt.show() 
1979  
1980     The input quantiles can be any shape of array, as long as the last 
1981     axis labels the components. 
1982  
1983     Alternatively, the object may be called (as a function) to fix the degrees 
1984     of freedom and scale parameters, returning a "frozen" Wishart random 
1985     variable: 
1986  
1987     >>> rv = wishart(df=1, scale=1) 
1988     >>> # Frozen object with the same methods but holding the given 
1989     >>> # degrees of freedom and scale fixed. 
1990  
1991     """
1992 
1993     def __init__(self, seed=None):
1994         super().__init__(seed)
1995         self.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(self.__doc__, wishart_docdict_params)
1996 
1997     def __call__(self, df=None, scale=None, seed=None):
1998         """Create a frozen Wishart distribution. 
1999  
2000         See `wishart_frozen` for more information. 
2001         """
2002         return wishart_frozen(df, scale, seed)
2003 
2004     def _process_parameters(self, df, scale):
2005         if scale is None:
2006             scale = 1.0
2007         scale = np.asarray(scale, dtype=float)
2008 
2009         if scale.ndim == 0:
2010             scale = scale[np.newaxis, np.newaxis]
2011         elif scale.ndim == 1:
2012             scale = np.diag(scale)
2013         elif scale.ndim == 2 and not scale.shape[0] == scale.shape[1]:
2014             raise ValueError("Array 'scale' must be square if it is two dimensional,"
2015                              f" but scale.scale = {str(scale.shape)}.")
2016         elif scale.ndim > 2:
2017             raise ValueError("Array 'scale' must be at most two-dimensional,"
2018                              " but scale.ndim = %d" % scale.ndim)
2019 
2020         dim = scale.shape[0]
2021 
2022         if df is None:
2023             df = dim
2024         elif not np.isscalar(df):
2025             raise ValueError("Degrees of freedom must be a scalar.")
2026         elif df <= dim - 1:
2027             raise ValueError("Degrees of freedom must be greater than the "
2028                              "dimension of scale matrix minus 1.")
2029 
2030         return dim, df, scale
2031 
2032     def _process_quantiles(self, x, dim):
2033         """ 
2034         Adjust quantiles array so that last axis labels the components of 
2035         each data point. 
2036         """
2037         x = np.asarray(x, dtype=float)
2038 
2039         if x.ndim == 0:
2040             x = x * np.eye(dim)[:, :, np.newaxis]
2041         if x.ndim == 1:
2042             if dim == 1:
2043                 x = x[np.newaxis, np.newaxis, :]
2044             else:
2045                 x = np.diag(x)[:, :, np.newaxis]
2046         elif x.ndim == 2:
2047             if not x.shape[0] == x.shape[1]:
2048                 raise ValueError(
2049                     "Quantiles must be square if they are two dimensional,"
2050                     f" but x.shape = {str(x.shape)}.")
2051             x = x[:, :, np.newaxis]
2052         elif x.ndim == 3:
2053             if not x.shape[0] == x.shape[1]:
2054                 raise ValueError(
2055                     "Quantiles must be square in the first two dimensions "
2056                     f"if they are three dimensional, but x.shape = {str(x.shape)}.")
2057         elif x.ndim > 3:
2058             raise ValueError("Quantiles must be at most two-dimensional with"
2059                              " an additional dimension for multiple"
2060                              "components, but x.ndim = %d" % x.ndim)
2061 
2062         # Now we have 3-dim array; should have shape [dim, dim, *]
2063         if not x.shape[0:2] == (dim, dim):
2064             raise ValueError('Quantiles have incompatible dimensions: should'
2065                              f' be {(dim, dim)}, got {x.shape[0:2]}.')
2066 
2067         return x
2068 
2069     def _process_size(self, size):
2070         size = np.asarray(size)
2071 
2072         if size.ndim == 0:
2073             size = size[np.newaxis]
2074         elif size.ndim > 1:
2075             raise ValueError('Size must be an integer or tuple of integers;'
2076                  ' thus must have dimension <= 1.'
2077                  f' Got size.ndim = {str(tuple(size))}')
2078         n = size.prod()
2079         shape = tuple(size)
2080 
2081         return n, shape
2082 
2083     def _logpdf(self, x, dim, df, scale, log_det_scale, C):
2084         """Log of the Wishart probability density function. 
2085  
2086         Parameters 
2087         ---------- 
2088         x : ndarray 
2089             Points at which to evaluate the log of the probability 
2090             density function 
2091         dim : int 
2092             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2093         df : int 
2094             Degrees of freedom 
2095         scale : ndarray 
2096             Scale matrix 
2097         log_det_scale : float 
2098             Logarithm of the determinant of the scale matrix 
2099         C : ndarray 
2100             Cholesky factorization of the scale matrix, lower triangular. 
2101  
2102         Notes 
2103         ----- 
2104         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2105         called directly; use 'logpdf' instead. 
2106  
2107         """
2108         # log determinant of x
2109         # Note: x has components along the last axis, so that x.T has
2110         # components alone the 0-th axis. Then since det(A) = det(A'), this
2111         # gives us a 1-dim vector of determinants
2112 
2113         # Retrieve tr(scale^{-1} x)
2114         log_det_x = np.empty(x.shape[-1])
2115         scale_inv_x = np.empty(x.shape)
2116         tr_scale_inv_x = np.empty(x.shape[-1])
2117         for i in range(x.shape[-1]):
2118             _, log_det_x[i] = self._cholesky_logdet(x[:, :, i])
2119             scale_inv_x[:, :, i] = scipy.linalg.cho_solve((C, True), x[:, :, i])
2120             tr_scale_inv_x[i] = scale_inv_x[:, :, i].trace()
2121 
2122         # Log PDF
2123         out = ((0.5 * (df - dim - 1) * log_det_x - 0.5 * tr_scale_inv_x) -
2124                (0.5 * df * dim * _LOG_2 + 0.5 * df * log_det_scale +
2125                 multigammaln(0.5*df, dim)))
2126 
2127         return out
2128 
2129     def logpdf(self, x, df, scale):
2130         """Log of the Wishart probability density function. 
2131  
2132         Parameters 
2133         ---------- 
2134         x : array_like 
2135             Quantiles, with the last axis of `x` denoting the components. 
2136             Each quantile must be a symmetric positive definite matrix. 
2137         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2138  
2139         Returns 
2140         ------- 
2141         pdf : ndarray 
2142             Log of the probability density function evaluated at `x` 
2143  
2144         Notes 
2145         ----- 
2146         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
2147  
2148         """
2149         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2150         x = self._process_quantiles(x, dim)
2151 
2152         # Cholesky decomposition of scale, get log(det(scale))
2153         C, log_det_scale = self._cholesky_logdet(scale)
2154 
2155         out = self._logpdf(x, dim, df, scale, log_det_scale, C)
2156         return _squeeze_output(out)
2157 
2158     def pdf(self, x, df, scale):
2159         """Wishart probability density function. 
2160  
2161         Parameters 
2162         ---------- 
2163         x : array_like 
2164             Quantiles, with the last axis of `x` denoting the components. 
2165             Each quantile must be a symmetric positive definite matrix. 
2166         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2167  
2168         Returns 
2169         ------- 
2170         pdf : ndarray 
2171             Probability density function evaluated at `x` 
2172  
2173         Notes 
2174         ----- 
2175         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
2176  
2177         """
2178         return np.exp(self.logpdf(x, df, scale))
2179 
2180     def _mean(self, dim, df, scale):
2181         """Mean of the Wishart distribution. 
2182  
2183         Parameters 
2184         ---------- 
2185         dim : int 
2186             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2187         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2188  
2189         Notes 
2190         ----- 
2191         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2192         called directly; use 'mean' instead. 
2193  
2194         """
2195         return df * scale
2196 
2197     def mean(self, df, scale):
2198         """Mean of the Wishart distribution. 
2199  
2200         Parameters 
2201         ---------- 
2202         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2203  
2204         Returns 
2205         ------- 
2206         mean : float 
2207             The mean of the distribution 
2208         """
2209         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2210         out = self._mean(dim, df, scale)
2211         return _squeeze_output(out)
2212 
2213     def _mode(self, dim, df, scale):
2214         """Mode of the Wishart distribution. 
2215  
2216         Parameters 
2217         ---------- 
2218         dim : int 
2219             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2220         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2221  
2222         Notes 
2223         ----- 
2224         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2225         called directly; use 'mode' instead. 
2226  
2227         """
2228         if df >= dim + 1:
2229             out = (df-dim-1) * scale
2230         else:
2231             out = None
2232         return out
2233 
2234     def mode(self, df, scale):
2235         """Mode of the Wishart distribution 
2236  
2237         Only valid if the degrees of freedom are greater than the dimension of 
2238         the scale matrix. 
2239  
2240         Parameters 
2241         ---------- 
2242         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2243  
2244         Returns 
2245         ------- 
2246         mode : float or None 
2247             The Mode of the distribution 
2248         """
2249         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2250         out = self._mode(dim, df, scale)
2251         return _squeeze_output(out) if out is not None else out
2252 
2253     def _var(self, dim, df, scale):
2254         """Variance of the Wishart distribution. 
2255  
2256         Parameters 
2257         ---------- 
2258         dim : int 
2259             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2260         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2261  
2262         Notes 
2263         ----- 
2264         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2265         called directly; use 'var' instead. 
2266  
2267         """
2268         var = scale**2
2269         diag = scale.diagonal()  # 1 x dim array
2270         var += np.outer(diag, diag)
2271         var *= df
2272         return var
2273 
2274     def var(self, df, scale):
2275         """Variance of the Wishart distribution. 
2276  
2277         Parameters 
2278         ---------- 
2279         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2280  
2281         Returns 
2282         ------- 
2283         var : float 
2284             The variance of the distribution 
2285         """
2286         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2287         out = self._var(dim, df, scale)
2288         return _squeeze_output(out)
2289 
2290     def _standard_rvs(self, n, shape, dim, df, random_state):
2291         """ 
2292         Parameters 
2293         ---------- 
2294         n : integer 
2295             Number of variates to generate 
2296         shape : iterable 
2297             Shape of the variates to generate 
2298         dim : int 
2299             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2300         df : int 
2301             Degrees of freedom 
2302         random_state : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, 
2303                         `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
2304  
2305             If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
2306             singleton is used. 
2307             If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
2308             seeded with `seed`. 
2309             If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance 
2310             then that instance is used. 
2311  
2312         Notes 
2313         ----- 
2314         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2315         called directly; use 'rvs' instead. 
2316  
2317         """
2318         # Random normal variates for off-diagonal elements
2319         n_tril = dim * (dim-1) // 2
2320         covariances = random_state.normal(
2321             size=n*n_tril).reshape(shape+(n_tril,))
2322 
2323         # Random chi-square variates for diagonal elements
2324         variances = (np.r_[[random_state.chisquare(df-(i+1)+1, size=n)**0.5
2325                             for i in range(dim)]].reshape((dim,) +
2326                                                           shape[::-1]).T)
2327 
2328         # Create the A matri(ces) - lower triangular
2329         A = np.zeros(shape + (dim, dim))
2330 
2331         # Input the covariances
2332         size_idx = tuple([slice(None, None, None)]*len(shape))
2333         tril_idx = np.tril_indices(dim, k=-1)
2334         A[size_idx + tril_idx] = covariances
2335 
2336         # Input the variances
2337         diag_idx = np.diag_indices(dim)
2338         A[size_idx + diag_idx] = variances
2339 
2340         return A
2341 
2342     def _rvs(self, n, shape, dim, df, C, random_state):
2343         """Draw random samples from a Wishart distribution. 
2344  
2345         Parameters 
2346         ---------- 
2347         n : integer 
2348             Number of variates to generate 
2349         shape : iterable 
2350             Shape of the variates to generate 
2351         dim : int 
2352             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2353         df : int 
2354             Degrees of freedom 
2355         C : ndarray 
2356             Cholesky factorization of the scale matrix, lower triangular. 
2357         %(_doc_random_state)s 
2358  
2359         Notes 
2360         ----- 
2361         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2362         called directly; use 'rvs' instead. 
2363  
2364         """
2365         random_state = self._get_random_state(random_state)
2366         # Calculate the matrices A, which are actually lower triangular
2367         # Cholesky factorizations of a matrix B such that B ~ W(df, I)
2368         A = self._standard_rvs(n, shape, dim, df, random_state)
2369 
2370         # Calculate SA = C A A' C', where SA ~ W(df, scale)
2371         # Note: this is the product of a (lower) (lower) (lower)' (lower)'
2372         #       or, denoting B = AA', it is C B C' where C is the lower
2373         #       triangular Cholesky factorization of the scale matrix.
2374         #       this appears to conflict with the instructions in [1]_, which
2375         #       suggest that it should be D' B D where D is the lower
2376         #       triangular factorization of the scale matrix. However, it is
2377         #       meant to refer to the Bartlett (1933) representation of a
2378         #       Wishart random variate as L A A' L' where L is lower triangular
2379         #       so it appears that understanding D' to be upper triangular
2380         #       is either a typo in or misreading of [1]_.
2381         for index in np.ndindex(shape):
2382             CA = np.dot(C, A[index])
2383             A[index] = np.dot(CA, CA.T)
2384 
2385         return A
2386 
2387     def rvs(self, df, scale, size=1, random_state=None):
2388         """Draw random samples from a Wishart distribution. 
2389  
2390         Parameters 
2391         ---------- 
2392         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2393         size : integer or iterable of integers, optional 
2394             Number of samples to draw (default 1). 
2395         %(_doc_random_state)s 
2396  
2397         Returns 
2398         ------- 
2399         rvs : ndarray 
2400             Random variates of shape (`size`) + (``dim``, ``dim``), where 
2401             ``dim`` is the dimension of the scale matrix. 
2402  
2403         Notes 
2404         ----- 
2405         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
2406  
2407         """
2408         n, shape = self._process_size(size)
2409         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2410 
2411         # Cholesky decomposition of scale
2412         C = scipy.linalg.cholesky(scale, lower=True)
2413 
2414         out = self._rvs(n, shape, dim, df, C, random_state)
2415 
2416         return _squeeze_output(out)
2417 
2418     def _entropy(self, dim, df, log_det_scale):
2419         """Compute the differential entropy of the Wishart. 
2420  
2421         Parameters 
2422         ---------- 
2423         dim : int 
2424             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2425         df : int 
2426             Degrees of freedom 
2427         log_det_scale : float 
2428             Logarithm of the determinant of the scale matrix 
2429  
2430         Notes 
2431         ----- 
2432         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2433         called directly; use 'entropy' instead. 
2434  
2435         """
2436         return (
2437             0.5 * (dim+1) * log_det_scale +
2438             0.5 * dim * (dim+1) * _LOG_2 +
2439             multigammaln(0.5*df, dim) -
2440             0.5 * (df - dim - 1) * np.sum(
2441                 [psi(0.5*(df + 1 - (i+1))) for i in range(dim)]
2442             ) +
2443             0.5 * df * dim
2444         )
2445 
2446     def entropy(self, df, scale):
2447         """Compute the differential entropy of the Wishart. 
2448  
2449         Parameters 
2450         ---------- 
2451         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2452  
2453         Returns 
2454         ------- 
2455         h : scalar 
2456             Entropy of the Wishart distribution 
2457  
2458         Notes 
2459         ----- 
2460         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
2461  
2462         """
2463         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2464         _, log_det_scale = self._cholesky_logdet(scale)
2465         return self._entropy(dim, df, log_det_scale)
2466 
2467     def _cholesky_logdet(self, scale):
2468         """Compute Cholesky decomposition and determine (log(det(scale)). 
2469  
2470         Parameters 
2471         ---------- 
2472         scale : ndarray 
2473             Scale matrix. 
2474  
2475         Returns 
2476         ------- 
2477         c_decomp : ndarray 
2478             The Cholesky decomposition of `scale`. 
2479         logdet : scalar 
2480             The log of the determinant of `scale`. 
2481  
2482         Notes 
2483         ----- 
2484         This computation of ``logdet`` is equivalent to 
2485         ``np.linalg.slogdet(scale)``.  It is ~2x faster though. 
2486  
2487         """
2488         c_decomp = scipy.linalg.cholesky(scale, lower=True)
2489         logdet = 2 * np.sum(np.log(c_decomp.diagonal()))
2490         return c_decomp, logdet
2491 
2492 
2493 wishart = wishart_gen()

2496 class wishart_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
2497     """Create a frozen Wishart distribution. 
2498  
2499     Parameters 
2500     ---------- 
2501     df : array_like 
2502         Degrees of freedom of the distribution 
2503     scale : array_like 
2504         Scale matrix of the distribution 
2505     seed : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
2506         If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
2507         singleton is used. 
2508         If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
2509         seeded with `seed`. 
2510         If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance then 
2511         that instance is used. 
2512  
2513     """
2514     def __init__(self, df, scale, seed=None):
2515         self._dist = wishart_gen(seed)
2516         self.dim, self.df, self.scale = self._dist._process_parameters(
2517             df, scale)
2518         self.C, self.log_det_scale = self._dist._cholesky_logdet(self.scale)
2519 
2520     def logpdf(self, x):
2521         x = self._dist._process_quantiles(x, self.dim)
2522 
2523         out = self._dist._logpdf(x, self.dim, self.df, self.scale,
2524                                  self.log_det_scale, self.C)
2525         return _squeeze_output(out)
2526 
2527     def pdf(self, x):
2528         return np.exp(self.logpdf(x))
2529 
2530     def mean(self):
2531         out = self._dist._mean(self.dim, self.df, self.scale)
2532         return _squeeze_output(out)
2533 
2534     def mode(self):
2535         out = self._dist._mode(self.dim, self.df, self.scale)
2536         return _squeeze_output(out) if out is not None else out
2537 
2538     def var(self):
2539         out = self._dist._var(self.dim, self.df, self.scale)
2540         return _squeeze_output(out)
2541 
2542     def rvs(self, size=1, random_state=None):
2543         n, shape = self._dist._process_size(size)
2544         out = self._dist._rvs(n, shape, self.dim, self.df,
2545                               self.C, random_state)
2546         return _squeeze_output(out)
2547 
2548     def entropy(self):
2549         return self._dist._entropy(self.dim, self.df, self.log_det_scale)
2550

2552 # Set frozen generator docstrings from corresponding docstrings in
2553 # Wishart and fill in default strings in class docstrings
2554 for name in ['logpdf', 'pdf', 'mean', 'mode', 'var', 'rvs', 'entropy']:
2555     method = wishart_gen.__dict__[name]
2556     method_frozen = wishart_frozen.__dict__[name]
2557     method_frozen.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(
2558         method.__doc__, wishart_docdict_noparams)
2559     method.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(method.__doc__, wishart_docdict_params)

2561 
2562 class invwishart_gen(wishart_gen):
2563     r"""An inverse Wishart random variable. 
2564  
2565     The `df` keyword specifies the degrees of freedom. The `scale` keyword 
2566     specifies the scale matrix, which must be symmetric and positive definite. 
2567     In this context, the scale matrix is often interpreted in terms of a 
2568     multivariate normal covariance matrix. 
2569  
2570     Methods 
2571     ------- 
2572     pdf(x, df, scale) 
2573         Probability density function. 
2574     logpdf(x, df, scale) 
2575         Log of the probability density function. 
2576     rvs(df, scale, size=1, random_state=None) 
2577         Draw random samples from an inverse Wishart distribution. 
2578     entropy(df, scale) 
2579         Differential entropy of the distribution. 
2580  
2581     Parameters 
2582     ---------- 
2583     %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2584     %(_doc_random_state)s 
2585  
2586     Raises 
2587     ------ 
2588     scipy.linalg.LinAlgError 
2589         If the scale matrix `scale` is not positive definite. 
2590  
2591     See Also 
2592     -------- 
2593     wishart 
2594  
2595     Notes 
2596     ----- 
2597     %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
2598  
2599     The scale matrix `scale` must be a symmetric positive definite 
2600     matrix. Singular matrices, including the symmetric positive semi-definite 
2601     case, are not supported. Symmetry is not checked; only the lower triangular 
2602     portion is used. 
2603  
2604     The inverse Wishart distribution is often denoted 
2605  
2606     .. math:: 
2607  
2608         W_p^{-1}(\nu, \Psi) 
2609  
2610     where :math:`\nu` is the degrees of freedom and :math:`\Psi` is the 
2611     :math:`p \times p` scale matrix. 
2612  
2613     The probability density function for `invwishart` has support over positive 
2614     definite matrices :math:`S`; if :math:`S \sim W^{-1}_p(\nu, \Sigma)`, 
2615     then its PDF is given by: 
2616  
2617     .. math:: 
2618  
2619         f(S) = \frac{|\Sigma|^\frac{\nu}{2}}{2^{ \frac{\nu p}{2} } 
2620                |S|^{\frac{\nu + p + 1}{2}} \Gamma_p \left(\frac{\nu}{2} \right)} 
2621                \exp\left( -tr(\Sigma S^{-1}) / 2 \right) 
2622  
2623     If :math:`S \sim W_p^{-1}(\nu, \Psi)` (inverse Wishart) then 
2624     :math:`S^{-1} \sim W_p(\nu, \Psi^{-1})` (Wishart). 
2625  
2626     If the scale matrix is 1-dimensional and equal to one, then the inverse 
2627     Wishart distribution :math:`W_1(\nu, 1)` collapses to the 
2628     inverse Gamma distribution with parameters shape = :math:`\frac{\nu}{2}` 
2629     and scale = :math:`\frac{1}{2}`. 
2630  
2631     Instead of inverting a randomly generated Wishart matrix as described in [2], 
2632     here the algorithm in [4] is used to directly generate a random inverse-Wishart 
2633     matrix without inversion. 
2634  
2635     .. versionadded:: 0.16.0 
2636  
2637     References 
2638     ---------- 
2639     .. [1] M.L. Eaton, "Multivariate Statistics: A Vector Space Approach", 
2640            Wiley, 1983. 
2641     .. [2] M.C. Jones, "Generating Inverse Wishart Matrices", Communications 
2642            in Statistics - Simulation and Computation, vol. 14.2, pp.511-514, 
2643            1985. 
2644     .. [3] Gupta, M. and Srivastava, S. "Parametric Bayesian Estimation of 
2645            Differential Entropy and Relative Entropy". Entropy 12, 818 - 843. 
2646            2010. 
2647     .. [4] S.D. Axen, "Efficiently generating inverse-Wishart matrices and 
2648            their Cholesky factors", :arXiv:`2310.15884v1`. 2023. 
2649  
2650     Examples 
2651     -------- 
2652     >>> import numpy as np 
2653     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
2654     >>> from scipy.stats import invwishart, invgamma 
2655     >>> x = np.linspace(0.01, 1, 100) 
2656     >>> iw = invwishart.pdf(x, df=6, scale=1) 
2657     >>> iw[:3] 
2658     array([  1.20546865e-15,   5.42497807e-06,   4.45813929e-03]) 
2659     >>> ig = invgamma.pdf(x, 6/2., scale=1./2) 
2660     >>> ig[:3] 
2661     array([  1.20546865e-15,   5.42497807e-06,   4.45813929e-03]) 
2662     >>> plt.plot(x, iw) 
2663     >>> plt.show() 
2664  
2665     The input quantiles can be any shape of array, as long as the last 
2666     axis labels the components. 
2667  
2668     Alternatively, the object may be called (as a function) to fix the degrees 
2669     of freedom and scale parameters, returning a "frozen" inverse Wishart 
2670     random variable: 
2671  
2672     >>> rv = invwishart(df=1, scale=1) 
2673     >>> # Frozen object with the same methods but holding the given 
2674     >>> # degrees of freedom and scale fixed. 
2675  
2676     """
2677 
2678     def __init__(self, seed=None):
2679         super().__init__(seed)
2680         self.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(self.__doc__, wishart_docdict_params)
2681 
2682     def __call__(self, df=None, scale=None, seed=None):
2683         """Create a frozen inverse Wishart distribution. 
2684  
2685         See `invwishart_frozen` for more information. 
2686  
2687         """
2688         return invwishart_frozen(df, scale, seed)
2689 
2690     def _logpdf(self, x, dim, df, log_det_scale, C):
2691         """Log of the inverse Wishart probability density function. 
2692  
2693         Parameters 
2694         ---------- 
2695         x : ndarray 
2696             Points at which to evaluate the log of the probability 
2697             density function. 
2698         dim : int 
2699             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2700         df : int 
2701             Degrees of freedom 
2702         log_det_scale : float 
2703             Logarithm of the determinant of the scale matrix 
2704         C : ndarray 
2705             Cholesky factorization of the scale matrix, lower triangular. 
2706  
2707         Notes 
2708         ----- 
2709         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2710         called directly; use 'logpdf' instead. 
2711  
2712         """
2713         # Retrieve tr(scale x^{-1})
2714         log_det_x = np.empty(x.shape[-1])
2715         tr_scale_x_inv = np.empty(x.shape[-1])
2716         trsm = get_blas_funcs(('trsm'), (x,))
2717         if dim > 1:
2718             for i in range(x.shape[-1]):
2719                 Cx, log_det_x[i] = self._cholesky_logdet(x[:, :, i])
2720                 A = trsm(1., Cx, C, side=0, lower=True)
2721                 tr_scale_x_inv[i] = np.linalg.norm(A)**2
2722         else:
2723             log_det_x[:] = np.log(x[0, 0])
2724             tr_scale_x_inv[:] = C[0, 0]**2 / x[0, 0]
2725 
2726         # Log PDF
2727         out = ((0.5 * df * log_det_scale - 0.5 * tr_scale_x_inv) -
2728                (0.5 * df * dim * _LOG_2 + 0.5 * (df + dim + 1) * log_det_x) -
2729                multigammaln(0.5*df, dim))
2730 
2731         return out
2732 
2733     def logpdf(self, x, df, scale):
2734         """Log of the inverse Wishart probability density function. 
2735  
2736         Parameters 
2737         ---------- 
2738         x : array_like 
2739             Quantiles, with the last axis of `x` denoting the components. 
2740             Each quantile must be a symmetric positive definite matrix. 
2741         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2742  
2743         Returns 
2744         ------- 
2745         pdf : ndarray 
2746             Log of the probability density function evaluated at `x` 
2747  
2748         Notes 
2749         ----- 
2750         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
2751  
2752         """
2753         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2754         x = self._process_quantiles(x, dim)
2755         C, log_det_scale = self._cholesky_logdet(scale)
2756         out = self._logpdf(x, dim, df, log_det_scale, C)
2757         return _squeeze_output(out)
2758 
2759     def pdf(self, x, df, scale):
2760         """Inverse Wishart probability density function. 
2761  
2762         Parameters 
2763         ---------- 
2764         x : array_like 
2765             Quantiles, with the last axis of `x` denoting the components. 
2766             Each quantile must be a symmetric positive definite matrix. 
2767         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2768  
2769         Returns 
2770         ------- 
2771         pdf : ndarray 
2772             Probability density function evaluated at `x` 
2773  
2774         Notes 
2775         ----- 
2776         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
2777  
2778         """
2779         return np.exp(self.logpdf(x, df, scale))
2780 
2781     def _mean(self, dim, df, scale):
2782         """Mean of the inverse Wishart distribution. 
2783  
2784         Parameters 
2785         ---------- 
2786         dim : int 
2787             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2788         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2789  
2790         Notes 
2791         ----- 
2792         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2793         called directly; use 'mean' instead. 
2794  
2795         """
2796         if df > dim + 1:
2797             out = scale / (df - dim - 1)
2798         else:
2799             out = None
2800         return out
2801 
2802     def mean(self, df, scale):
2803         """Mean of the inverse Wishart distribution. 
2804  
2805         Only valid if the degrees of freedom are greater than the dimension of 
2806         the scale matrix plus one. 
2807  
2808         Parameters 
2809         ---------- 
2810         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2811  
2812         Returns 
2813         ------- 
2814         mean : float or None 
2815             The mean of the distribution 
2816  
2817         """
2818         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2819         out = self._mean(dim, df, scale)
2820         return _squeeze_output(out) if out is not None else out
2821 
2822     def _mode(self, dim, df, scale):
2823         """Mode of the inverse Wishart distribution. 
2824  
2825         Parameters 
2826         ---------- 
2827         dim : int 
2828             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2829         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2830  
2831         Notes 
2832         ----- 
2833         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2834         called directly; use 'mode' instead. 
2835  
2836         """
2837         return scale / (df + dim + 1)
2838 
2839     def mode(self, df, scale):
2840         """Mode of the inverse Wishart distribution. 
2841  
2842         Parameters 
2843         ---------- 
2844         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2845  
2846         Returns 
2847         ------- 
2848         mode : float 
2849             The Mode of the distribution 
2850  
2851         """
2852         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2853         out = self._mode(dim, df, scale)
2854         return _squeeze_output(out)
2855 
2856     def _var(self, dim, df, scale):
2857         """Variance of the inverse Wishart distribution. 
2858  
2859         Parameters 
2860         ---------- 
2861         dim : int 
2862             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2863         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2864  
2865         Notes 
2866         ----- 
2867         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2868         called directly; use 'var' instead. 
2869  
2870         """
2871         if df > dim + 3:
2872             var = (df - dim + 1) * scale**2
2873             diag = scale.diagonal()  # 1 x dim array
2874             var += (df - dim - 1) * np.outer(diag, diag)
2875             var /= (df - dim) * (df - dim - 1)**2 * (df - dim - 3)
2876         else:
2877             var = None
2878         return var
2879 
2880     def var(self, df, scale):
2881         """Variance of the inverse Wishart distribution. 
2882  
2883         Only valid if the degrees of freedom are greater than the dimension of 
2884         the scale matrix plus three. 
2885  
2886         Parameters 
2887         ---------- 
2888         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
2889  
2890         Returns 
2891         ------- 
2892         var : float 
2893             The variance of the distribution 
2894         """
2895         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
2896         out = self._var(dim, df, scale)
2897         return _squeeze_output(out) if out is not None else out
2898 
2899     def _inv_standard_rvs(self, n, shape, dim, df, random_state):
2900         """ 
2901         Parameters 
2902         ---------- 
2903         n : integer 
2904             Number of variates to generate 
2905         shape : iterable 
2906             Shape of the variates to generate 
2907         dim : int 
2908             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2909         df : int 
2910             Degrees of freedom 
2911         random_state : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, 
2912                         `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
2913  
2914             If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
2915             singleton is used. 
2916             If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
2917             seeded with `seed`. 
2918             If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance 
2919             then that instance is used. 
2920  
2921         Returns 
2922         ------- 
2923         A : ndarray 
2924             Random variates of shape (`shape`) + (``dim``, ``dim``). 
2925             Each slice `A[..., :, :]` is lower-triangular, and its 
2926             inverse is the lower Cholesky factor of a draw from 
2927             `invwishart(df, np.eye(dim))`. 
2928  
2929         Notes 
2930         ----- 
2931         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2932         called directly; use 'rvs' instead. 
2933  
2934         """
2935         A = np.zeros(shape + (dim, dim))
2936 
2937         # Random normal variates for off-diagonal elements
2938         tri_rows, tri_cols = np.tril_indices(dim, k=-1)
2939         n_tril = dim * (dim-1) // 2
2940         A[..., tri_rows, tri_cols] = random_state.normal(
2941             size=(*shape, n_tril),
2942         )
2943 
2944         # Random chi variates for diagonal elements
2945         rows = np.arange(dim)
2946         chi_dfs = (df - dim + 1) + rows
2947         A[..., rows, rows] = random_state.chisquare(
2948             df=chi_dfs, size=(*shape, dim),
2949         )**0.5
2950 
2951         return A
2952 
2953     def _rvs(self, n, shape, dim, df, C, random_state):
2954         """Draw random samples from an inverse Wishart distribution. 
2955  
2956         Parameters 
2957         ---------- 
2958         n : integer 
2959             Number of variates to generate 
2960         shape : iterable 
2961             Shape of the variates to generate 
2962         dim : int 
2963             Dimension of the scale matrix 
2964         df : int 
2965             Degrees of freedom 
2966         C : ndarray 
2967             Cholesky factorization of the scale matrix, lower triangular. 
2968         %(_doc_random_state)s 
2969  
2970         Notes 
2971         ----- 
2972         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
2973         called directly; use 'rvs' instead. 
2974  
2975         """
2976         random_state = self._get_random_state(random_state)
2977         # Get random draws A such that inv(A) ~ iW(df, I)
2978         A = self._inv_standard_rvs(n, shape, dim, df, random_state)
2979 
2980         # Calculate SA = (CA)'^{-1} (CA)^{-1} ~ iW(df, scale)
2981         trsm = get_blas_funcs(('trsm'), (A,))
2982         trmm = get_blas_funcs(('trmm'), (A,))
2983 
2984         for index in np.ndindex(A.shape[:-2]):
2985             if dim > 1:
2986                 # Calculate CA
2987                 # Get CA = C A^{-1} via triangular solver
2988                 CA = trsm(1., A[index], C, side=1, lower=True)
2989                 # get SA
2990                 A[index] = trmm(1., CA, CA, side=1, lower=True, trans_a=True)
2991             else:
2992                 A[index][0, 0] = (C[0, 0] / A[index][0, 0])**2
2993 
2994         return A
2995 
2996     def rvs(self, df, scale, size=1, random_state=None):
2997         """Draw random samples from an inverse Wishart distribution. 
2998  
2999         Parameters 
3000         ---------- 
3001         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3002         size : integer or iterable of integers, optional 
3003             Number of samples to draw (default 1). 
3004         %(_doc_random_state)s 
3005  
3006         Returns 
3007         ------- 
3008         rvs : ndarray 
3009             Random variates of shape (`size`) + (``dim``, ``dim``), where 
3010             ``dim`` is the dimension of the scale matrix. 
3011  
3012         Notes 
3013         ----- 
3014         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
3015  
3016         """
3017         n, shape = self._process_size(size)
3018         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
3019 
3020         # Cholesky decomposition of scale
3021         C = scipy.linalg.cholesky(scale, lower=True)
3022 
3023         out = self._rvs(n, shape, dim, df, C, random_state)
3024 
3025         return _squeeze_output(out)
3026 
3027     def _entropy(self, dim, df, log_det_scale):
3028         # reference: eq. (17) from ref. 3
3029         psi_eval_points = [0.5 * (df - dim + i) for i in range(1, dim + 1)]
3030         psi_eval_points = np.asarray(psi_eval_points)
3031         return multigammaln(0.5 * df, dim) + 0.5 * dim * df + \
3032             0.5 * (dim + 1) * (log_det_scale - _LOG_2) - \
3033             0.5 * (df + dim + 1) * \
3034             psi(psi_eval_points, out=psi_eval_points).sum()
3035 
3036     def entropy(self, df, scale):
3037         dim, df, scale = self._process_parameters(df, scale)
3038         _, log_det_scale = self._cholesky_logdet(scale)
3039         return self._entropy(dim, df, log_det_scale)
3040 
3041 
3042 invwishart = invwishart_gen()
3043 
3044 
3045 class invwishart_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
3046     def __init__(self, df, scale, seed=None):
3047         """Create a frozen inverse Wishart distribution. 
3048  
3049         Parameters 
3050         ---------- 
3051         df : array_like 
3052             Degrees of freedom of the distribution 
3053         scale : array_like 
3054             Scale matrix of the distribution 
3055         seed : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`}, optional 
3056             If `seed` is None the `numpy.random.Generator` singleton is used. 
3057             If `seed` is an int, a new ``Generator`` instance is used, 
3058             seeded with `seed`. 
3059             If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` instance then that instance is 
3060             used. 
3061  
3062         """
3063         self._dist = invwishart_gen(seed)
3064         self.dim, self.df, self.scale = self._dist._process_parameters(
3065             df, scale
3066         )
3067 
3068         # Get the determinant via Cholesky factorization
3069         self.C = scipy.linalg.cholesky(self.scale, lower=True)
3070         self.log_det_scale = 2 * np.sum(np.log(self.C.diagonal()))
3071 
3072     def logpdf(self, x):
3073         x = self._dist._process_quantiles(x, self.dim)
3074         out = self._dist._logpdf(x, self.dim, self.df,
3075                                  self.log_det_scale, self.C)
3076         return _squeeze_output(out)
3077 
3078     def pdf(self, x):
3079         return np.exp(self.logpdf(x))
3080 
3081     def mean(self):
3082         out = self._dist._mean(self.dim, self.df, self.scale)
3083         return _squeeze_output(out) if out is not None else out
3084 
3085     def mode(self):
3086         out = self._dist._mode(self.dim, self.df, self.scale)
3087         return _squeeze_output(out)
3088 
3089     def var(self):
3090         out = self._dist._var(self.dim, self.df, self.scale)
3091         return _squeeze_output(out) if out is not None else out
3092 
3093     def rvs(self, size=1, random_state=None):
3094         n, shape = self._dist._process_size(size)
3095 
3096         out = self._dist._rvs(n, shape, self.dim, self.df,
3097                               self.C, random_state)
3098 
3099         return _squeeze_output(out)
3100 
3101     def entropy(self):
3102         return self._dist._entropy(self.dim, self.df, self.log_det_scale)
3103

3106 # inverse Wishart and fill in default strings in class docstrings
3107 for name in ['logpdf', 'pdf', 'mean', 'mode', 'var', 'rvs']:
3108     method = invwishart_gen.__dict__[name]
3109     method_frozen = wishart_frozen.__dict__[name]
3110     method_frozen.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(
3111         method.__doc__, wishart_docdict_noparams)
3112     method.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(method.__doc__, wishart_docdict_params)

3146 class multinomial_gen(multi_rv_generic):
3147     r"""A multinomial random variable. 
3148  
3149     Methods 
3150     ------- 
3151     pmf(x, n, p) 
3152         Probability mass function. 
3153     logpmf(x, n, p) 
3154         Log of the probability mass function. 
3155     rvs(n, p, size=1, random_state=None) 
3156         Draw random samples from a multinomial distribution. 
3157     entropy(n, p) 
3158         Compute the entropy of the multinomial distribution. 
3159     cov(n, p) 
3160         Compute the covariance matrix of the multinomial distribution. 
3161  
3162     Parameters 
3163     ---------- 
3164     %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3165     %(_doc_random_state)s 
3166  
3167     Notes 
3168     ----- 
3169     %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
3170  
3171     The probability mass function for `multinomial` is 
3172  
3173     .. math:: 
3174  
3175         f(x) = \frac{n!}{x_1! \cdots x_k!} p_1^{x_1} \cdots p_k^{x_k}, 
3176  
3177     supported on :math:`x=(x_1, \ldots, x_k)` where each :math:`x_i` is a 
3178     nonnegative integer and their sum is :math:`n`. 
3179  
3180     .. versionadded:: 0.19.0 
3181  
3182     Examples 
3183     -------- 
3184  
3185     >>> from scipy.stats import multinomial 
3186     >>> rv = multinomial(8, [0.3, 0.2, 0.5]) 
3187     >>> rv.pmf([1, 3, 4]) 
3188     0.042000000000000072 
3189  
3190     The multinomial distribution for :math:`k=2` is identical to the 
3191     corresponding binomial distribution (tiny numerical differences 
3192     notwithstanding): 
3193  
3194     >>> from scipy.stats import binom 
3195     >>> multinomial.pmf([3, 4], n=7, p=[0.4, 0.6]) 
3196     0.29030399999999973 
3197     >>> binom.pmf(3, 7, 0.4) 
3198     0.29030400000000012 
3199  
3200     The functions ``pmf``, ``logpmf``, ``entropy``, and ``cov`` support 
3201     broadcasting, under the convention that the vector parameters (``x`` and 
3202     ``p``) are interpreted as if each row along the last axis is a single 
3203     object. For instance: 
3204  
3205     >>> multinomial.pmf([[3, 4], [3, 5]], n=[7, 8], p=[.3, .7]) 
3206     array([0.2268945,  0.25412184]) 
3207  
3208     Here, ``x.shape == (2, 2)``, ``n.shape == (2,)``, and ``p.shape == (2,)``, 
3209     but following the rules mentioned above they behave as if the rows 
3210     ``[3, 4]`` and ``[3, 5]`` in ``x`` and ``[.3, .7]`` in ``p`` were a single 
3211     object, and as if we had ``x.shape = (2,)``, ``n.shape = (2,)``, and 
3212     ``p.shape = ()``. To obtain the individual elements without broadcasting, 
3213     we would do this: 
3214  
3215     >>> multinomial.pmf([3, 4], n=7, p=[.3, .7]) 
3216     0.2268945 
3217     >>> multinomial.pmf([3, 5], 8, p=[.3, .7]) 
3218     0.25412184 
3219  
3220     This broadcasting also works for ``cov``, where the output objects are 
3221     square matrices of size ``p.shape[-1]``. For example: 
3222  
3223     >>> multinomial.cov([4, 5], [[.3, .7], [.4, .6]]) 
3224     array([[[ 0.84, -0.84], 
3225             [-0.84,  0.84]], 
3226            [[ 1.2 , -1.2 ], 
3227             [-1.2 ,  1.2 ]]]) 
3228  
3229     In this example, ``n.shape == (2,)`` and ``p.shape == (2, 2)``, and 
3230     following the rules above, these broadcast as if ``p.shape == (2,)``. 
3231     Thus the result should also be of shape ``(2,)``, but since each output is 
3232     a :math:`2 \times 2` matrix, the result in fact has shape ``(2, 2, 2)``, 
3233     where ``result[0]`` is equal to ``multinomial.cov(n=4, p=[.3, .7])`` and 
3234     ``result[1]`` is equal to ``multinomial.cov(n=5, p=[.4, .6])``. 
3235  
3236     Alternatively, the object may be called (as a function) to fix the `n` and 
3237     `p` parameters, returning a "frozen" multinomial random variable: 
3238  
3239     >>> rv = multinomial(n=7, p=[.3, .7]) 
3240     >>> # Frozen object with the same methods but holding the given 
3241     >>> # degrees of freedom and scale fixed. 
3242  
3243     See also 
3244     -------- 
3245     scipy.stats.binom : The binomial distribution. 
3246     numpy.random.Generator.multinomial : Sampling from the multinomial distribution. 
3247     scipy.stats.multivariate_hypergeom : 
3248         The multivariate hypergeometric distribution. 
3249     """
3250 
3251     def __init__(self, seed=None):
3252         super().__init__(seed)
3253         self.__doc__ = \
3254             doccer.docformat(self.__doc__, multinomial_docdict_params)
3255 
3256     def __call__(self, n, p, seed=None):
3257         """Create a frozen multinomial distribution. 
3258  
3259         See `multinomial_frozen` for more information. 
3260         """
3261         return multinomial_frozen(n, p, seed)
3262 
3263     def _process_parameters(self, n, p, eps=1e-15):
3264         """Returns: n_, p_, npcond. 
3265  
3266         n_ and p_ are arrays of the correct shape; npcond is a boolean array 
3267         flagging values out of the domain. 
3268         """
3269         p = np.array(p, dtype=np.float64, copy=True)
3270         p_adjusted = 1. - p[..., :-1].sum(axis=-1)
3271         i_adjusted = np.abs(p_adjusted) > eps
3272         p[i_adjusted, -1] = p_adjusted[i_adjusted]
3273 
3274         # true for bad p
3275         pcond = np.any(p < 0, axis=-1)
3276         pcond |= np.any(p > 1, axis=-1)
3277 
3278         n = np.array(n, dtype=int, copy=True)
3279 
3280         # true for bad n
3281         ncond = n < 0
3282 
3283         return n, p, ncond | pcond
3284 
3285     def _process_quantiles(self, x, n, p):
3286         """Returns: x_, xcond. 
3287  
3288         x_ is an int array; xcond is a boolean array flagging values out of the 
3289         domain. 
3290         """
3291         xx = np.asarray(x, dtype=int)
3292 
3293         if xx.ndim == 0:
3294             raise ValueError("x must be an array.")
3295 
3296         if xx.size != 0 and not xx.shape[-1] == p.shape[-1]:
3297             raise ValueError("Size of each quantile should be size of p: "
3298                              "received %d, but expected %d." %
3299                              (xx.shape[-1], p.shape[-1]))
3300 
3301         # true for x out of the domain
3302         cond = np.any(xx != x, axis=-1)
3303         cond |= np.any(xx < 0, axis=-1)
3304         cond = cond | (np.sum(xx, axis=-1) != n)
3305 
3306         return xx, cond
3307 
3308     def _checkresult(self, result, cond, bad_value):
3309         result = np.asarray(result)
3310 
3311         if cond.ndim != 0:
3312             result[cond] = bad_value
3313         elif cond:
3314             if result.ndim == 0:
3315                 return bad_value
3316             result[...] = bad_value
3317         return result
3318 
3319     def _logpmf(self, x, n, p):
3320         return gammaln(n+1) + np.sum(xlogy(x, p) - gammaln(x+1), axis=-1)
3321 
3322     def logpmf(self, x, n, p):
3323         """Log of the Multinomial probability mass function. 
3324  
3325         Parameters 
3326         ---------- 
3327         x : array_like 
3328             Quantiles, with the last axis of `x` denoting the components. 
3329         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3330  
3331         Returns 
3332         ------- 
3333         logpmf : ndarray or scalar 
3334             Log of the probability mass function evaluated at `x` 
3335  
3336         Notes 
3337         ----- 
3338         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
3339         """
3340         n, p, npcond = self._process_parameters(n, p)
3341         x, xcond = self._process_quantiles(x, n, p)
3342 
3343         result = self._logpmf(x, n, p)
3344 
3345         # replace values for which x was out of the domain; broadcast
3346         # xcond to the right shape
3347         xcond_ = xcond | np.zeros(npcond.shape, dtype=np.bool_)
3348         result = self._checkresult(result, xcond_, -np.inf)
3349 
3350         # replace values bad for n or p; broadcast npcond to the right shape
3351         npcond_ = npcond | np.zeros(xcond.shape, dtype=np.bool_)
3352         return self._checkresult(result, npcond_, np.nan)
3353 
3354     def pmf(self, x, n, p):
3355         """Multinomial probability mass function. 
3356  
3357         Parameters 
3358         ---------- 
3359         x : array_like 
3360             Quantiles, with the last axis of `x` denoting the components. 
3361         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3362  
3363         Returns 
3364         ------- 
3365         pmf : ndarray or scalar 
3366             Probability density function evaluated at `x` 
3367  
3368         Notes 
3369         ----- 
3370         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
3371         """
3372         return np.exp(self.logpmf(x, n, p))
3373 
3374     def mean(self, n, p):
3375         """Mean of the Multinomial distribution. 
3376  
3377         Parameters 
3378         ---------- 
3379         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3380  
3381         Returns 
3382         ------- 
3383         mean : float 
3384             The mean of the distribution 
3385         """
3386         n, p, npcond = self._process_parameters(n, p)
3387         result = n[..., np.newaxis]*p
3388         return self._checkresult(result, npcond, np.nan)
3389 
3390     def cov(self, n, p):
3391         """Covariance matrix of the multinomial distribution. 
3392  
3393         Parameters 
3394         ---------- 
3395         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3396  
3397         Returns 
3398         ------- 
3399         cov : ndarray 
3400             The covariance matrix of the distribution 
3401         """
3402         n, p, npcond = self._process_parameters(n, p)
3403 
3404         nn = n[..., np.newaxis, np.newaxis]
3405         result = nn * np.einsum('...j,...k->...jk', -p, p)
3406 
3407         # change the diagonal
3408         for i in range(p.shape[-1]):
3409             result[..., i, i] += n*p[..., i]
3410 
3411         return self._checkresult(result, npcond, np.nan)
3412 
3413     def entropy(self, n, p):
3414         r"""Compute the entropy of the multinomial distribution. 
3415  
3416         The entropy is computed using this expression: 
3417  
3418         .. math:: 
3419  
3420             f(x) = - \log n! - n\sum_{i=1}^k p_i \log p_i + 
3421             \sum_{i=1}^k \sum_{x=0}^n \binom n x p_i^x(1-p_i)^{n-x} \log x! 
3422  
3423         Parameters 
3424         ---------- 
3425         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3426  
3427         Returns 
3428         ------- 
3429         h : scalar 
3430             Entropy of the Multinomial distribution 
3431  
3432         Notes 
3433         ----- 
3434         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
3435         """
3436         n, p, npcond = self._process_parameters(n, p)
3437 
3438         x = np.r_[1:np.max(n)+1]
3439 
3440         term1 = n*np.sum(entr(p), axis=-1)
3441         term1 -= gammaln(n+1)
3442 
3443         n = n[..., np.newaxis]
3444         new_axes_needed = max(p.ndim, n.ndim) - x.ndim + 1
3445         x.shape += (1,)*new_axes_needed
3446 
3447         term2 = np.sum(binom.pmf(x, n, p)*gammaln(x+1),
3448                        axis=(-1, -1-new_axes_needed))
3449 
3450         return self._checkresult(term1 + term2, npcond, np.nan)
3451 
3452     def rvs(self, n, p, size=None, random_state=None):
3453         """Draw random samples from a Multinomial distribution. 
3454  
3455         Parameters 
3456         ---------- 
3457         %(_doc_default_callparams)s 
3458         size : integer or iterable of integers, optional 
3459             Number of samples to draw (default 1). 
3460         %(_doc_random_state)s 
3461  
3462         Returns 
3463         ------- 
3464         rvs : ndarray or scalar 
3465             Random variates of shape (`size`, `len(p)`) 
3466  
3467         Notes 
3468         ----- 
3469         %(_doc_callparams_note)s 
3470         """
3471         n, p, npcond = self._process_parameters(n, p)
3472         random_state = self._get_random_state(random_state)
3473         return random_state.multinomial(n, p, size)
3474

3476 multinomial = multinomial_gen()

3479 class multinomial_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
3480     r"""Create a frozen Multinomial distribution. 
3481  
3482     Parameters 
3483     ---------- 
3484     n : int 
3485         number of trials 
3486     p: array_like 
3487         probability of a trial falling into each category; should sum to 1 
3488     seed : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
3489         If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
3490         singleton is used. 
3491         If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
3492         seeded with `seed`. 
3493         If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance then 
3494         that instance is used. 
3495     """
3496     def __init__(self, n, p, seed=None):
3497         self._dist = multinomial_gen(seed)
3498         self.n, self.p, self.npcond = self._dist._process_parameters(n, p)
3499 
3500         # monkey patch self._dist
3501         def _process_parameters(n, p):
3502             return self.n, self.p, self.npcond
3503 
3504         self._dist._process_parameters = _process_parameters
3505 
3506     def logpmf(self, x):
3507         return self._dist.logpmf(x, self.n, self.p)
3508 
3509     def pmf(self, x):
3510         return self._dist.pmf(x, self.n, self.p)
3511 
3512     def mean(self):
3513         return self._dist.mean(self.n, self.p)
3514 
3515     def cov(self):
3516         return self._dist.cov(self.n, self.p)
3517 
3518     def entropy(self):
3519         return self._dist.entropy(self.n, self.p)
3520 
3521     def rvs(self, size=1, random_state=None):
3522         return self._dist.rvs(self.n, self.p, size, random_state)
3523

3531         method.__doc__, multinomial_docdict_noparams)

3536 class special_ortho_group_gen(multi_rv_generic):
3537     r"""A Special Orthogonal matrix (SO(N)) random variable. 
3538  
3539     Return a random rotation matrix, drawn from the Haar distribution 
3540     (the only uniform distribution on SO(N)) with a determinant of +1. 
3541  
3542     The `dim` keyword specifies the dimension N. 
3543  
3544     Methods 
3545     ------- 
3546     rvs(dim=None, size=1, random_state=None) 
3547         Draw random samples from SO(N). 
3548  
3549     Parameters 
3550     ---------- 
3551     dim : scalar 
3552         Dimension of matrices 
3553     seed : {None, int, np.random.RandomState, np.random.Generator}, optional 
3554         Used for drawing random variates. 
3555         If `seed` is `None`, the `~np.random.RandomState` singleton is used. 
3556         If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, seeded 
3557         with seed. 
3558         If `seed` is already a ``RandomState`` or ``Generator`` instance, 
3559         then that object is used. 
3560         Default is `None`. 
3561  
3562     Notes 
3563     ----- 
3564     This class is wrapping the random_rot code from the MDP Toolkit, 
3565     https://github.com/mdp-toolkit/mdp-toolkit 
3566  
3567     Return a random rotation matrix, drawn from the Haar distribution 
3568     (the only uniform distribution on SO(N)). 
3569     The algorithm is described in the paper 
3570     Stewart, G.W., "The efficient generation of random orthogonal 
3571     matrices with an application to condition estimators", SIAM Journal 
3572     on Numerical Analysis, 17(3), pp. 403-409, 1980. 
3573     For more information see 
3574     https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthogonal_matrix#Randomization 
3575  
3576     See also the similar `ortho_group`. For a random rotation in three 
3577     dimensions, see `scipy.spatial.transform.Rotation.random`. 
3578  
3579     Examples 
3580     -------- 
3581     >>> import numpy as np 
3582     >>> from scipy.stats import special_ortho_group 
3583     >>> x = special_ortho_group.rvs(3) 
3584  
3585     >>> np.dot(x, x.T) 
3586     array([[  1.00000000e+00,   1.13231364e-17,  -2.86852790e-16], 
3587            [  1.13231364e-17,   1.00000000e+00,  -1.46845020e-16], 
3588            [ -2.86852790e-16,  -1.46845020e-16,   1.00000000e+00]]) 
3589  
3590     >>> import scipy.linalg 
3591     >>> scipy.linalg.det(x) 
3592     1.0 
3593  
3594     This generates one random matrix from SO(3). It is orthogonal and 
3595     has a determinant of 1. 
3596  
3597     Alternatively, the object may be called (as a function) to fix the `dim` 
3598     parameter, returning a "frozen" special_ortho_group random variable: 
3599  
3600     >>> rv = special_ortho_group(5) 
3601     >>> # Frozen object with the same methods but holding the 
3602     >>> # dimension parameter fixed. 
3603  
3604     See Also 
3605     -------- 
3606     ortho_group, scipy.spatial.transform.Rotation.random 
3607  
3608     """
3609 
3610     def __init__(self, seed=None):
3611         super().__init__(seed)
3612         self.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(self.__doc__)
3613 
3614     def __call__(self, dim=None, seed=None):
3615         """Create a frozen SO(N) distribution. 
3616  
3617         See `special_ortho_group_frozen` for more information. 
3618         """
3619         return special_ortho_group_frozen(dim, seed=seed)
3620 
3621     def _process_parameters(self, dim):
3622         """Dimension N must be specified; it cannot be inferred."""
3623         if dim is None or not np.isscalar(dim) or dim <= 1 or dim != int(dim):
3624             raise ValueError("""Dimension of rotation must be specified, 
3625                                 and must be a scalar greater than 1.""")
3626 
3627         return dim
3628 
3629     def rvs(self, dim, size=1, random_state=None):
3630         """Draw random samples from SO(N). 
3631  
3632         Parameters 
3633         ---------- 
3634         dim : integer 
3635             Dimension of rotation space (N). 
3636         size : integer, optional 
3637             Number of samples to draw (default 1). 
3638  
3639         Returns 
3640         ------- 
3641         rvs : ndarray or scalar 
3642             Random size N-dimensional matrices, dimension (size, dim, dim) 
3643  
3644         """
3645         random_state = self._get_random_state(random_state)
3646 
3647         size = int(size)
3648         size = (size,) if size > 1 else ()
3649 
3650         dim = self._process_parameters(dim)
3651 
3652         # H represents a (dim, dim) matrix, while D represents the diagonal of
3653         # a (dim, dim) diagonal matrix. The algorithm that follows is
3654         # broadcasted on the leading shape in `size` to vectorize along
3655         # samples.
3656         H = np.empty(size + (dim, dim))
3657         H[..., :, :] = np.eye(dim)
3658         D = np.empty(size + (dim,))
3659 
3660         for n in range(dim-1):
3661 
3662             # x is a vector with length dim-n, xrow and xcol are views of it as
3663             # a row vector and column vector respectively. It's important they
3664             # are views and not copies because we are going to modify x
3665             # in-place.
3666             x = random_state.normal(size=size + (dim-n,))
3667             xrow = x[..., None, :]
3668             xcol = x[..., :, None]
3669 
3670             # This is the squared norm of x, without vectorization it would be
3671             # dot(x, x), to have proper broadcasting we use matmul and squeeze
3672             # out (convert to scalar) the resulting 1x1 matrix
3673             norm2 = np.matmul(xrow, xcol).squeeze((-2, -1))
3674 
3675             x0 = x[..., 0].copy()
3676             D[..., n] = np.where(x0 != 0, np.sign(x0), 1)
3677             x[..., 0] += D[..., n]*np.sqrt(norm2)
3678 
3679             # In renormalizing x we have to append an additional axis with
3680             # [..., None] to broadcast the scalar against the vector x
3681             x /= np.sqrt((norm2 - x0**2 + x[..., 0]**2) / 2.)[..., None]
3682 
3683             # Householder transformation, without vectorization the RHS can be
3684             # written as outer(H @ x, x) (apart from the slicing)
3685             H[..., :, n:] -= np.matmul(H[..., :, n:], xcol) * xrow
3686 
3687         D[..., -1] = (-1)**(dim-1)*D[..., :-1].prod(axis=-1)
3688 
3689         # Without vectorization this could be written as H = diag(D) @ H,
3690         # left-multiplication by a diagonal matrix amounts to multiplying each
3691         # row of H by an element of the diagonal, so we add a dummy axis for
3692         # the column index
3693         H *= D[..., :, None]
3694         return H
3695 
3696 
3697 special_ortho_group = special_ortho_group_gen()
3698 
3699 
3700 class special_ortho_group_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
3701     def __init__(self, dim=None, seed=None):
3702         """Create a frozen SO(N) distribution. 
3703  
3704         Parameters 
3705         ---------- 
3706         dim : scalar 
3707             Dimension of matrices 
3708         seed : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
3709             If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
3710             singleton is used. 
3711             If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
3712             seeded with `seed`. 
3713             If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance 
3714             then that instance is used. 
3715  
3716         Examples 
3717         -------- 
3718         >>> from scipy.stats import special_ortho_group 
3719         >>> g = special_ortho_group(5) 
3720         >>> x = g.rvs() 
3721  
3722         """ # numpy/numpydoc#87  # noqa: E501
3723         self._dist = special_ortho_group_gen(seed)
3724         self.dim = self._dist._process_parameters(dim)
3725 
3726     def rvs(self, size=1, random_state=None):
3727         return self._dist.rvs(self.dim, size, random_state)

3730 class ortho_group_gen(multi_rv_generic):
3731     r"""An Orthogonal matrix (O(N)) random variable. 
3732  
3733     Return a random orthogonal matrix, drawn from the O(N) Haar 
3734     distribution (the only uniform distribution on O(N)). 
3735  
3736     The `dim` keyword specifies the dimension N. 
3737  
3738     Methods 
3739     ------- 
3740     rvs(dim=None, size=1, random_state=None) 
3741         Draw random samples from O(N). 
3742  
3743     Parameters 
3744     ---------- 
3745     dim : scalar 
3746         Dimension of matrices 
3747     seed : {None, int, np.random.RandomState, np.random.Generator}, optional 
3748         Used for drawing random variates. 
3749         If `seed` is `None`, the `~np.random.RandomState` singleton is used. 
3750         If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, seeded 
3751         with seed. 
3752         If `seed` is already a ``RandomState`` or ``Generator`` instance, 
3753         then that object is used. 
3754         Default is `None`. 
3755  
3756     Notes 
3757     ----- 
3758     This class is closely related to `special_ortho_group`. 
3759  
3760     Some care is taken to avoid numerical error, as per the paper by Mezzadri. 
3761  
3762     References 
3763     ---------- 
3764     .. [1] F. Mezzadri, "How to generate random matrices from the classical 
3765            compact groups", :arXiv:`math-ph/0609050v2`. 
3766  
3767     Examples 
3768     -------- 
3769     >>> import numpy as np 
3770     >>> from scipy.stats import ortho_group 
3771     >>> x = ortho_group.rvs(3) 
3772  
3773     >>> np.dot(x, x.T) 
3774     array([[  1.00000000e+00,   1.13231364e-17,  -2.86852790e-16], 
3775            [  1.13231364e-17,   1.00000000e+00,  -1.46845020e-16], 
3776            [ -2.86852790e-16,  -1.46845020e-16,   1.00000000e+00]]) 
3777  
3778     >>> import scipy.linalg 
3779     >>> np.fabs(scipy.linalg.det(x)) 
3780     1.0 
3781  
3782     This generates one random matrix from O(3). It is orthogonal and 
3783     has a determinant of +1 or -1. 
3784  
3785     Alternatively, the object may be called (as a function) to fix the `dim` 
3786     parameter, returning a "frozen" ortho_group random variable: 
3787  
3788     >>> rv = ortho_group(5) 
3789     >>> # Frozen object with the same methods but holding the 
3790     >>> # dimension parameter fixed. 
3791  
3792     See Also 
3793     -------- 
3794     special_ortho_group 
3795     """
3796 
3797     def __init__(self, seed=None):
3798         super().__init__(seed)
3799         self.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(self.__doc__)
3800 
3801     def __call__(self, dim=None, seed=None):
3802         """Create a frozen O(N) distribution. 
3803  
3804         See `ortho_group_frozen` for more information. 
3805         """
3806         return ortho_group_frozen(dim, seed=seed)
3807 
3808     def _process_parameters(self, dim):
3809         """Dimension N must be specified; it cannot be inferred."""
3810         if dim is None or not np.isscalar(dim) or dim <= 1 or dim != int(dim):
3811             raise ValueError("Dimension of rotation must be specified,"
3812                              "and must be a scalar greater than 1.")
3813 
3814         return dim
3815 
3816     def rvs(self, dim, size=1, random_state=None):
3817         """Draw random samples from O(N). 
3818  
3819         Parameters 
3820         ---------- 
3821         dim : integer 
3822             Dimension of rotation space (N). 
3823         size : integer, optional 
3824             Number of samples to draw (default 1). 
3825  
3826         Returns 
3827         ------- 
3828         rvs : ndarray or scalar 
3829             Random size N-dimensional matrices, dimension (size, dim, dim) 
3830  
3831         """
3832         random_state = self._get_random_state(random_state)
3833 
3834         size = int(size)
3835 
3836         dim = self._process_parameters(dim)
3837 
3838         size = (size,) if size > 1 else ()
3839         z = random_state.normal(size=size + (dim, dim))
3840         q, r = np.linalg.qr(z)
3841         # The last two dimensions are the rows and columns of R matrices.
3842         # Extract the diagonals. Note that this eliminates a dimension.
3843         d = r.diagonal(offset=0, axis1=-2, axis2=-1)
3844         # Add back a dimension for proper broadcasting: we're dividing
3845         # each row of each R matrix by the diagonal of the R matrix.
3846         q *= (d/abs(d))[..., np.newaxis, :]  # to broadcast properly
3847         return q
3848 
3849 
3850 ortho_group = ortho_group_gen()
3851 
3852 
3853 class ortho_group_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
3854     def __init__(self, dim=None, seed=None):
3855         """Create a frozen O(N) distribution. 
3856  
3857         Parameters 
3858         ---------- 
3859         dim : scalar 
3860             Dimension of matrices 
3861         seed : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
3862             If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
3863             singleton is used. 
3864             If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
3865             seeded with `seed`. 
3866             If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance 
3867             then that instance is used. 
3868  
3869         Examples 
3870         -------- 
3871         >>> from scipy.stats import ortho_group 
3872         >>> g = ortho_group(5) 
3873         >>> x = g.rvs() 
3874

3876         self._dist = ortho_group_gen(seed)
3877         self.dim = self._dist._process_parameters(dim)
3878 
3879     def rvs(self, size=1, random_state=None):
3880         return self._dist.rvs(self.dim, size, random_state)
