5991 
5992 def _dirichlet_multinomial_check_parameters(alpha, n, x=None):
5993 
5994     alpha = np.asarray(alpha)
5995     n = np.asarray(n)
5996 
5997     if x is not None:
5998         # Ensure that `x` and `alpha` are arrays. If the shapes are
5999         # incompatible, NumPy will raise an appropriate error.
6000         try:
6001             x, alpha = np.broadcast_arrays(x, alpha)
6002         except ValueError as e:
6003             msg = "`x` and `alpha` must be broadcastable."
6004             raise ValueError(msg) from e
6005 
6006         x_int = np.floor(x)
6007         if np.any(x < 0) or np.any(x != x_int):
6008             raise ValueError("`x` must contain only non-negative integers.")
6009         x = x_int
6010 
6011     if np.any(alpha <= 0):
6012         raise ValueError("`alpha` must contain only positive values.")
6013 
6014     n_int = np.floor(n)
6015     if np.any(n <= 0) or np.any(n != n_int):
6016         raise ValueError("`n` must be a positive integer.")
6017     n = n_int
6018 
6019     sum_alpha = np.sum(alpha, axis=-1)
6020     sum_alpha, n = np.broadcast_arrays(sum_alpha, n)
6021 
6022     return (alpha, sum_alpha, n) if x is None else (alpha, sum_alpha, n, x)
6023 
6024 
6025 class dirichlet_multinomial_gen(multi_rv_generic):
6026     r"""A Dirichlet multinomial random variable. 
6027  
6028     The Dirichlet multinomial distribution is a compound probability 
6029     distribution: it is the multinomial distribution with number of trials 
6030     `n` and class probabilities ``p`` randomly sampled from a Dirichlet 
6031     distribution with concentration parameters ``alpha``. 
6032  
6033     Methods 
6034     ------- 
6035     logpmf(x, alpha, n): 
6036         Log of the probability mass function. 
6037     pmf(x, alpha, n): 
6038         Probability mass function. 
6039     mean(alpha, n): 
6040         Mean of the Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6041     var(alpha, n): 
6042         Variance of the Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6043     cov(alpha, n): 
6044         The covariance of the Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6045  
6046     Parameters 
6047     ---------- 
6048     %(_dirichlet_mn_doc_default_callparams)s 
6049     %(_doc_random_state)s 
6050  
6051     See Also 
6052     -------- 
6053     scipy.stats.dirichlet : The dirichlet distribution. 
6054     scipy.stats.multinomial : The multinomial distribution. 
6055  
6056     References 
6057     ---------- 
6058     .. [1] Dirichlet-multinomial distribution, Wikipedia, 
6059            https://www.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dirichlet-multinomial_distribution 
6060  
6061     Examples 
6062     -------- 
6063     >>> from scipy.stats import dirichlet_multinomial 
6064  
6065     Get the PMF 
6066  
6067     >>> n = 6  # number of trials 
6068     >>> alpha = [3, 4, 5]  # concentration parameters 
6069     >>> x = [1, 2, 3]  # counts 
6070     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.pmf(x, alpha, n) 
6071     0.08484162895927604 
6072  
6073     If the sum of category counts does not equal the number of trials, 
6074     the probability mass is zero. 
6075  
6076     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.pmf(x, alpha, n=7) 
6077     0.0 
6078  
6079     Get the log of the PMF 
6080  
6081     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.logpmf(x, alpha, n) 
6082     -2.4669689491013327 
6083  
6084     Get the mean 
6085  
6086     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.mean(alpha, n) 
6087     array([1.5, 2. , 2.5]) 
6088  
6089     Get the variance 
6090  
6091     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.var(alpha, n) 
6092     array([1.55769231, 1.84615385, 2.01923077]) 
6093  
6094     Get the covariance 
6095  
6096     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.cov(alpha, n) 
6097     array([[ 1.55769231, -0.69230769, -0.86538462], 
6098            [-0.69230769,  1.84615385, -1.15384615], 
6099            [-0.86538462, -1.15384615,  2.01923077]]) 
6100  
6101     Alternatively, the object may be called (as a function) to fix the 
6102     `alpha` and `n` parameters, returning a "frozen" Dirichlet multinomial 
6103     random variable. 
6104  
6105     >>> dm = dirichlet_multinomial(alpha, n) 
6106     >>> dm.pmf(x) 
6107     0.08484162895927579 
6108  
6109     All methods are fully vectorized. Each element of `x` and `alpha` is 
6110     a vector (along the last axis), each element of `n` is an 
6111     integer (scalar), and the result is computed element-wise. 
6112  
6113     >>> x = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]] 
6114     >>> alpha = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]] 
6115     >>> n = [6, 15] 
6116     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.pmf(x, alpha, n) 
6117     array([0.06493506, 0.02626937]) 
6118  
6119     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.cov(alpha, n).shape  # both covariance matrices 
6120     (2, 3, 3) 
6121  
6122     Broadcasting according to standard NumPy conventions is supported. Here, 
6123     we have four sets of concentration parameters (each a two element vector) 
6124     for each of three numbers of trials (each a scalar). 
6125  
6126     >>> alpha = [[3, 4], [4, 5], [5, 6], [6, 7]] 
6127     >>> n = [[6], [7], [8]] 
6128     >>> dirichlet_multinomial.mean(alpha, n).shape 
6129     (3, 4, 2) 
6130  
6131     """
6132     def __init__(self, seed=None):
6133         super().__init__(seed)
6134         self.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(self.__doc__,
6135                                         dirichlet_mn_docdict_params)
6136 
6137     def __call__(self, alpha, n, seed=None):
6138         return dirichlet_multinomial_frozen(alpha, n, seed=seed)
6139 
6140     def logpmf(self, x, alpha, n):
6141         """The log of the probability mass function. 
6142  
6143         Parameters 
6144         ---------- 
6145         x: ndarray 
6146             Category counts (non-negative integers). Must be broadcastable 
6147             with shape parameter ``alpha``. If multidimensional, the last axis 
6148             must correspond with the categories. 
6149         %(_dirichlet_mn_doc_default_callparams)s 
6150  
6151         Returns 
6152         ------- 
6153         out: ndarray or scalar 
6154             Log of the probability mass function. 
6155  
6156         """
6157 
6158         a, Sa, n, x = _dirichlet_multinomial_check_parameters(alpha, n, x)
6159 
6160         out = np.asarray(loggamma(Sa) + loggamma(n + 1) - loggamma(n + Sa))
6161         out += (loggamma(x + a) - (loggamma(a) + loggamma(x + 1))).sum(axis=-1)
6162         np.place(out, n != x.sum(axis=-1), -np.inf)
6163         return out[()]
6164 
6165     def pmf(self, x, alpha, n):
6166         """Probability mass function for a Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6167  
6168         Parameters 
6169         ---------- 
6170         x: ndarray 
6171             Category counts (non-negative integers). Must be broadcastable 
6172             with shape parameter ``alpha``. If multidimensional, the last axis 
6173             must correspond with the categories. 
6174         %(_dirichlet_mn_doc_default_callparams)s 
6175  
6176         Returns 
6177         ------- 
6178         out: ndarray or scalar 
6179             Probability mass function. 
6180  
6181         """
6182         return np.exp(self.logpmf(x, alpha, n))
6183 
6184     def mean(self, alpha, n):
6185         """Mean of a Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6186  
6187         Parameters 
6188         ---------- 
6189         %(_dirichlet_mn_doc_default_callparams)s 
6190  
6191         Returns 
6192         ------- 
6193         out: ndarray 
6194             Mean of a Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6195  
6196         """
6197         a, Sa, n = _dirichlet_multinomial_check_parameters(alpha, n)
6198         n, Sa = n[..., np.newaxis], Sa[..., np.newaxis]
6199         return n * a / Sa
6200 
6201     def var(self, alpha, n):
6202         """The variance of the Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6203  
6204         Parameters 
6205         ---------- 
6206         %(_dirichlet_mn_doc_default_callparams)s 
6207  
6208         Returns 
6209         ------- 
6210         out: array_like 
6211             The variances of the components of the distribution. This is 
6212             the diagonal of the covariance matrix of the distribution. 
6213  
6214         """
6215         a, Sa, n = _dirichlet_multinomial_check_parameters(alpha, n)
6216         n, Sa = n[..., np.newaxis], Sa[..., np.newaxis]
6217         return n * a / Sa * (1 - a/Sa) * (n + Sa) / (1 + Sa)
6218 
6219     def cov(self, alpha, n):
6220         """Covariance matrix of a Dirichlet multinomial distribution. 
6221  
6222         Parameters 
6223         ---------- 
6224         %(_dirichlet_mn_doc_default_callparams)s 
6225  
6226         Returns 
6227         ------- 
6228         out : array_like 
6229             The covariance matrix of the distribution. 
6230  
6231         """
6232         a, Sa, n = _dirichlet_multinomial_check_parameters(alpha, n)
6233         var = dirichlet_multinomial.var(a, n)
6234 
6235         n, Sa = n[..., np.newaxis, np.newaxis], Sa[..., np.newaxis, np.newaxis]
6236         aiaj = a[..., :, np.newaxis] * a[..., np.newaxis, :]
6237         cov = -n * aiaj / Sa ** 2 * (n + Sa) / (1 + Sa)
6238 
6239         ii = np.arange(cov.shape[-1])
6240         cov[..., ii, ii] = var
6241         return cov
6242 
6243 
6244 dirichlet_multinomial = dirichlet_multinomial_gen()
6245

6247 class dirichlet_multinomial_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
6248     def __init__(self, alpha, n, seed=None):
6249         alpha, Sa, n = _dirichlet_multinomial_check_parameters(alpha, n)
6250         self.alpha = alpha
6251         self.n = n
6252         self._dist = dirichlet_multinomial_gen(seed)
6253 
6254     def logpmf(self, x):
6255         return self._dist.logpmf(x, self.alpha, self.n)
6256 
6257     def pmf(self, x):
6258         return self._dist.pmf(x, self.alpha, self.n)
6259 
6260     def mean(self):
6261         return self._dist.mean(self.alpha, self.n)
6262 
6263     def var(self):
6264         return self._dist.var(self.alpha, self.n)
6265 
6266     def cov(self):
6267         return self._dist.cov(self.alpha, self.n)

6270 # Set frozen generator docstrings from corresponding docstrings in
6271 # dirichlet_multinomial and fill in default strings in class docstrings.
6272 for name in ['logpmf', 'pmf', 'mean', 'var', 'cov']:
6273     method = dirichlet_multinomial_gen.__dict__[name]
6274     method_frozen = dirichlet_multinomial_frozen.__dict__[name]
6275     method_frozen.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(
6276         method.__doc__, dirichlet_mn_docdict_noparams)
6277     method.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(method.__doc__,
6278                                       dirichlet_mn_docdict_params)

6280 
6281 class vonmises_fisher_gen(multi_rv_generic):
6282     r"""A von Mises-Fisher variable. 
6283  
6284     The `mu` keyword specifies the mean direction vector. The `kappa` keyword 
6285     specifies the concentration parameter. 
6286  
6287     Methods 
6288     ------- 
6289     pdf(x, mu=None, kappa=1) 
6290         Probability density function. 
6291     logpdf(x, mu=None, kappa=1) 
6292         Log of the probability density function. 
6293     rvs(mu=None, kappa=1, size=1, random_state=None) 
6294         Draw random samples from a von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6295     entropy(mu=None, kappa=1) 
6296         Compute the differential entropy of the von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6297     fit(data) 
6298         Fit a von Mises-Fisher distribution to data. 
6299  
6300     Parameters 
6301     ---------- 
6302     mu : array_like 
6303         Mean direction of the distribution. Must be a one-dimensional unit 
6304         vector of norm 1. 
6305     kappa : float 
6306         Concentration parameter. Must be positive. 
6307     seed : {None, int, np.random.RandomState, np.random.Generator}, optional 
6308         Used for drawing random variates. 
6309         If `seed` is `None`, the `~np.random.RandomState` singleton is used. 
6310         If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, seeded 
6311         with seed. 
6312         If `seed` is already a ``RandomState`` or ``Generator`` instance, 
6313         then that object is used. 
6314         Default is `None`. 
6315  
6316     See Also 
6317     -------- 
6318     scipy.stats.vonmises : Von-Mises Fisher distribution in 2D on a circle 
6319     uniform_direction : uniform distribution on the surface of a hypersphere 
6320  
6321     Notes 
6322     ----- 
6323     The von Mises-Fisher distribution is a directional distribution on the 
6324     surface of the unit hypersphere. The probability density 
6325     function of a unit vector :math:`\mathbf{x}` is 
6326  
6327     .. math:: 
6328  
6329         f(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{\kappa^{d/2-1}}{(2\pi)^{d/2}I_{d/2-1}(\kappa)} 
6330                \exp\left(\kappa \mathbf{\mu}^T\mathbf{x}\right), 
6331  
6332     where :math:`\mathbf{\mu}` is the mean direction, :math:`\kappa` the 
6333     concentration parameter, :math:`d` the dimension and :math:`I` the 
6334     modified Bessel function of the first kind. As :math:`\mu` represents 
6335     a direction, it must be a unit vector or in other words, a point 
6336     on the hypersphere: :math:`\mathbf{\mu}\in S^{d-1}`. :math:`\kappa` is a 
6337     concentration parameter, which means that it must be positive 
6338     (:math:`\kappa>0`) and that the distribution becomes more narrow with 
6339     increasing :math:`\kappa`. In that sense, the reciprocal value 
6340     :math:`1/\kappa` resembles the variance parameter of the normal 
6341     distribution. 
6342  
6343     The von Mises-Fisher distribution often serves as an analogue of the 
6344     normal distribution on the sphere. Intuitively, for unit vectors, a 
6345     useful distance measure is given by the angle :math:`\alpha` between 
6346     them. This is exactly what the scalar product 
6347     :math:`\mathbf{\mu}^T\mathbf{x}=\cos(\alpha)` in the 
6348     von Mises-Fisher probability density function describes: the angle 
6349     between the mean direction :math:`\mathbf{\mu}` and the vector 
6350     :math:`\mathbf{x}`. The larger the angle between them, the smaller the 
6351     probability to observe :math:`\mathbf{x}` for this particular mean 
6352     direction :math:`\mathbf{\mu}`. 
6353  
6354     In dimensions 2 and 3, specialized algorithms are used for fast sampling 
6355     [2]_, [3]_. For dimensions of 4 or higher the rejection sampling algorithm 
6356     described in [4]_ is utilized. This implementation is partially based on 
6357     the geomstats package [5]_, [6]_. 
6358  
6359     .. versionadded:: 1.11 
6360  
6361     References 
6362     ---------- 
6363     .. [1] Von Mises-Fisher distribution, Wikipedia, 
6364            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Mises%E2%80%93Fisher_distribution 
6365     .. [2] Mardia, K., and Jupp, P. Directional statistics. Wiley, 2000. 
6366     .. [3] J. Wenzel. Numerically stable sampling of the von Mises Fisher 
6367            distribution on S2. 
6368            https://www.mitsuba-renderer.org/~wenzel/files/vmf.pdf 
6369     .. [4] Wood, A. Simulation of the von mises fisher distribution. 
6370            Communications in statistics-simulation and computation 23, 
6371            1 (1994), 157-164. https://doi.org/10.1080/03610919408813161 
6372     .. [5] geomstats, Github. MIT License. Accessed: 06.01.2023. 
6373            https://github.com/geomstats/geomstats 
6374     .. [6] Miolane, N. et al. Geomstats:  A Python Package for Riemannian 
6375            Geometry in Machine Learning. Journal of Machine Learning Research 
6376            21 (2020). http://jmlr.org/papers/v21/19-027.html 
6377  
6378     Examples 
6379     -------- 
6380     **Visualization of the probability density** 
6381  
6382     Plot the probability density in three dimensions for increasing 
6383     concentration parameter. The density is calculated by the ``pdf`` 
6384     method. 
6385  
6386     >>> import numpy as np 
6387     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
6388     >>> from scipy.stats import vonmises_fisher 
6389     >>> from matplotlib.colors import Normalize 
6390     >>> n_grid = 100 
6391     >>> u = np.linspace(0, np.pi, n_grid) 
6392     >>> v = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, n_grid) 
6393     >>> u_grid, v_grid = np.meshgrid(u, v) 
6394     >>> vertices = np.stack([np.cos(v_grid) * np.sin(u_grid), 
6395     ...                      np.sin(v_grid) * np.sin(u_grid), 
6396     ...                      np.cos(u_grid)], 
6397     ...                     axis=2) 
6398     >>> x = np.outer(np.cos(v), np.sin(u)) 
6399     >>> y = np.outer(np.sin(v), np.sin(u)) 
6400     >>> z = np.outer(np.ones_like(u), np.cos(u)) 
6401     >>> def plot_vmf_density(ax, x, y, z, vertices, mu, kappa): 
6402     ...     vmf = vonmises_fisher(mu, kappa) 
6403     ...     pdf_values = vmf.pdf(vertices) 
6404     ...     pdfnorm = Normalize(vmin=pdf_values.min(), vmax=pdf_values.max()) 
6405     ...     ax.plot_surface(x, y, z, rstride=1, cstride=1, 
6406     ...                     facecolors=plt.cm.viridis(pdfnorm(pdf_values)), 
6407     ...                     linewidth=0) 
6408     ...     ax.set_aspect('equal') 
6409     ...     ax.view_init(azim=-130, elev=0) 
6410     ...     ax.axis('off') 
6411     ...     ax.set_title(rf"$\kappa={kappa}$") 
6412     >>> fig, axes = plt.subplots(nrows=1, ncols=3, figsize=(9, 4), 
6413     ...                          subplot_kw={"projection": "3d"}) 
6414     >>> left, middle, right = axes 
6415     >>> mu = np.array([-np.sqrt(0.5), -np.sqrt(0.5), 0]) 
6416     >>> plot_vmf_density(left, x, y, z, vertices, mu, 5) 
6417     >>> plot_vmf_density(middle, x, y, z, vertices, mu, 20) 
6418     >>> plot_vmf_density(right, x, y, z, vertices, mu, 100) 
6419     >>> plt.subplots_adjust(top=1, bottom=0.0, left=0.0, right=1.0, wspace=0.) 
6420     >>> plt.show() 
6421  
6422     As we increase the concentration parameter, the points are getting more 
6423     clustered together around the mean direction. 
6424  
6425     **Sampling** 
6426  
6427     Draw 5 samples from the distribution using the ``rvs`` method resulting 
6428     in a 5x3 array. 
6429  
6430     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng() 
6431     >>> mu = np.array([0, 0, 1]) 
6432     >>> samples = vonmises_fisher(mu, 20).rvs(5, random_state=rng) 
6433     >>> samples 
6434     array([[ 0.3884594 , -0.32482588,  0.86231516], 
6435            [ 0.00611366, -0.09878289,  0.99509023], 
6436            [-0.04154772, -0.01637135,  0.99900239], 
6437            [-0.14613735,  0.12553507,  0.98126695], 
6438            [-0.04429884, -0.23474054,  0.97104814]]) 
6439  
6440     These samples are unit vectors on the sphere :math:`S^2`. To verify, 
6441     let us calculate their euclidean norms: 
6442  
6443     >>> np.linalg.norm(samples, axis=1) 
6444     array([1., 1., 1., 1., 1.]) 
6445  
6446     Plot 20 observations drawn from the von Mises-Fisher distribution for 
6447     increasing concentration parameter :math:`\kappa`. The red dot highlights 
6448     the mean direction :math:`\mu`. 
6449  
6450     >>> def plot_vmf_samples(ax, x, y, z, mu, kappa): 
6451     ...     vmf = vonmises_fisher(mu, kappa) 
6452     ...     samples = vmf.rvs(20) 
6453     ...     ax.plot_surface(x, y, z, rstride=1, cstride=1, linewidth=0, 
6454     ...                     alpha=0.2) 
6455     ...     ax.scatter(samples[:, 0], samples[:, 1], samples[:, 2], c='k', s=5) 
6456     ...     ax.scatter(mu[0], mu[1], mu[2], c='r', s=30) 
6457     ...     ax.set_aspect('equal') 
6458     ...     ax.view_init(azim=-130, elev=0) 
6459     ...     ax.axis('off') 
6460     ...     ax.set_title(rf"$\kappa={kappa}$") 
6461     >>> mu = np.array([-np.sqrt(0.5), -np.sqrt(0.5), 0]) 
6462     >>> fig, axes = plt.subplots(nrows=1, ncols=3, 
6463     ...                          subplot_kw={"projection": "3d"}, 
6464     ...                          figsize=(9, 4)) 
6465     >>> left, middle, right = axes 
6466     >>> plot_vmf_samples(left, x, y, z, mu, 5) 
6467     >>> plot_vmf_samples(middle, x, y, z, mu, 20) 
6468     >>> plot_vmf_samples(right, x, y, z, mu, 100) 
6469     >>> plt.subplots_adjust(top=1, bottom=0.0, left=0.0, 
6470     ...                     right=1.0, wspace=0.) 
6471     >>> plt.show() 
6472  
6473     The plots show that with increasing concentration :math:`\kappa` the 
6474     resulting samples are centered more closely around the mean direction. 
6475  
6476     **Fitting the distribution parameters** 
6477  
6478     The distribution can be fitted to data using the ``fit`` method returning 
6479     the estimated parameters. As a toy example let's fit the distribution to 
6480     samples drawn from a known von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6481  
6482     >>> mu, kappa = np.array([0, 0, 1]), 20 
6483     >>> samples = vonmises_fisher(mu, kappa).rvs(1000, random_state=rng) 
6484     >>> mu_fit, kappa_fit = vonmises_fisher.fit(samples) 
6485     >>> mu_fit, kappa_fit 
6486     (array([0.01126519, 0.01044501, 0.99988199]), 19.306398751730995) 
6487  
6488     We see that the estimated parameters `mu_fit` and `kappa_fit` are 
6489     very close to the ground truth parameters. 
6490  
6491     """
6492     def __init__(self, seed=None):
6493         super().__init__(seed)
6494 
6495     def __call__(self, mu=None, kappa=1, seed=None):
6496         """Create a frozen von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6497  
6498         See `vonmises_fisher_frozen` for more information. 
6499         """
6500         return vonmises_fisher_frozen(mu, kappa, seed=seed)
6501 
6502     def _process_parameters(self, mu, kappa):
6503         """ 
6504         Infer dimensionality from mu and ensure that mu is a one-dimensional 
6505         unit vector and kappa positive. 
6506         """
6507         mu = np.asarray(mu)
6508         if mu.ndim > 1:
6509             raise ValueError("'mu' must have one-dimensional shape.")
6510         if not np.allclose(np.linalg.norm(mu), 1.):
6511             raise ValueError("'mu' must be a unit vector of norm 1.")
6512         if not mu.size > 1:
6513             raise ValueError("'mu' must have at least two entries.")
6514         kappa_error_msg = "'kappa' must be a positive scalar."
6515         if not np.isscalar(kappa) or kappa < 0:
6516             raise ValueError(kappa_error_msg)
6517         if float(kappa) == 0.:
6518             raise ValueError("For 'kappa=0' the von Mises-Fisher distribution "
6519                              "becomes the uniform distribution on the sphere "
6520                              "surface. Consider using "
6521                              "'scipy.stats.uniform_direction' instead.")
6522         dim = mu.size
6523 
6524         return dim, mu, kappa
6525 
6526     def _check_data_vs_dist(self, x, dim):
6527         if x.shape[-1] != dim:
6528             raise ValueError("The dimensionality of the last axis of 'x' must "
6529                              "match the dimensionality of the "
6530                              "von Mises Fisher distribution.")
6531         if not np.allclose(np.linalg.norm(x, axis=-1), 1.):
6532             msg = "'x' must be unit vectors of norm 1 along last dimension."
6533             raise ValueError(msg)
6534 
6535     def _log_norm_factor(self, dim, kappa):
6536         # normalization factor is given by
6537         # c = kappa**(dim/2-1)/((2*pi)**(dim/2)*I[dim/2-1](kappa))
6538         #   = kappa**(dim/2-1)*exp(-kappa) /
6539         #     ((2*pi)**(dim/2)*I[dim/2-1](kappa)*exp(-kappa)
6540         #   = kappa**(dim/2-1)*exp(-kappa) /
6541         #     ((2*pi)**(dim/2)*ive[dim/2-1](kappa)
6542         # Then the log is given by
6543         # log c = 1/2*(dim -1)*log(kappa) - kappa - -1/2*dim*ln(2*pi) -
6544         #         ive[dim/2-1](kappa)
6545         halfdim = 0.5 * dim
6546         return (0.5 * (dim - 2)*np.log(kappa) - halfdim * _LOG_2PI -
6547                 np.log(ive(halfdim - 1, kappa)) - kappa)
6548 
6549     def _logpdf(self, x, dim, mu, kappa):
6550         """Log of the von Mises-Fisher probability density function. 
6551  
6552         As this function does no argument checking, it should not be 
6553         called directly; use 'logpdf' instead. 
6554  
6555         """
6556         x = np.asarray(x)
6557         self._check_data_vs_dist(x, dim)
6558         dotproducts = np.einsum('i,...i->...', mu, x)
6559         return self._log_norm_factor(dim, kappa) + kappa * dotproducts
6560 
6561     def logpdf(self, x, mu=None, kappa=1):
6562         """Log of the von Mises-Fisher probability density function. 
6563  
6564         Parameters 
6565         ---------- 
6566         x : array_like 
6567             Points at which to evaluate the log of the probability 
6568             density function. The last axis of `x` must correspond 
6569             to unit vectors of the same dimensionality as the distribution. 
6570         mu : array_like, default: None 
6571             Mean direction of the distribution. Must be a one-dimensional unit 
6572             vector of norm 1. 
6573         kappa : float, default: 1 
6574             Concentration parameter. Must be positive. 
6575  
6576         Returns 
6577         ------- 
6578         logpdf : ndarray or scalar 
6579             Log of the probability density function evaluated at `x`. 
6580  
6581         """
6582         dim, mu, kappa = self._process_parameters(mu, kappa)
6583         return self._logpdf(x, dim, mu, kappa)
6584 
6585     def pdf(self, x, mu=None, kappa=1):
6586         """Von Mises-Fisher probability density function. 
6587  
6588         Parameters 
6589         ---------- 
6590         x : array_like 
6591             Points at which to evaluate the probability 
6592             density function. The last axis of `x` must correspond 
6593             to unit vectors of the same dimensionality as the distribution. 
6594         mu : array_like 
6595             Mean direction of the distribution. Must be a one-dimensional unit 
6596             vector of norm 1. 
6597         kappa : float 
6598             Concentration parameter. Must be positive. 
6599  
6600         Returns 
6601         ------- 
6602         pdf : ndarray or scalar 
6603             Probability density function evaluated at `x`. 
6604  
6605         """
6606         dim, mu, kappa = self._process_parameters(mu, kappa)
6607         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, dim, mu, kappa))
6608 
6609     def _rvs_2d(self, mu, kappa, size, random_state):
6610         """ 
6611         In 2D, the von Mises-Fisher distribution reduces to the 
6612         von Mises distribution which can be efficiently sampled by numpy. 
6613         This method is much faster than the general rejection 
6614         sampling based algorithm. 
6615  
6616         """
6617         mean_angle = np.arctan2(mu[1], mu[0])
6618         angle_samples = random_state.vonmises(mean_angle, kappa, size=size)
6619         samples = np.stack([np.cos(angle_samples), np.sin(angle_samples)],
6620                            axis=-1)
6621         return samples
6622 
6623     def _rvs_3d(self, kappa, size, random_state):
6624         """ 
6625         Generate samples from a von Mises-Fisher distribution 
6626         with mu = [1, 0, 0] and kappa. Samples then have to be 
6627         rotated towards the desired mean direction mu. 
6628         This method is much faster than the general rejection 
6629         sampling based algorithm. 
6630         Reference: https://www.mitsuba-renderer.org/~wenzel/files/vmf.pdf 
6631  
6632         """
6633         if size is None:
6634             sample_size = 1
6635         else:
6636             sample_size = size
6637 
6638         # compute x coordinate acc. to equation from section 3.1
6639         x = random_state.random(sample_size)
6640         x = 1. + np.log(x + (1. - x) * np.exp(-2 * kappa))/kappa
6641 
6642         # (y, z) are random 2D vectors that only have to be
6643         # normalized accordingly. Then (x, y z) follow a VMF distribution
6644         temp = np.sqrt(1. - np.square(x))
6645         uniformcircle = _sample_uniform_direction(2, sample_size, random_state)
6646         samples = np.stack([x, temp * uniformcircle[..., 0],
6647                             temp * uniformcircle[..., 1]],
6648                            axis=-1)
6649         if size is None:
6650             samples = np.squeeze(samples)
6651         return samples
6652 
6653     def _rejection_sampling(self, dim, kappa, size, random_state):
6654         """ 
6655         Generate samples from a n-dimensional von Mises-Fisher distribution 
6656         with mu = [1, 0, ..., 0] and kappa via rejection sampling. 
6657         Samples then have to be rotated towards the desired mean direction mu. 
6658         Reference: https://doi.org/10.1080/03610919408813161 
6659         """
6660         dim_minus_one = dim - 1
6661         # calculate number of requested samples
6662         if size is not None:
6663             if not np.iterable(size):
6664                 size = (size, )
6665             n_samples = math.prod(size)
6666         else:
6667             n_samples = 1
6668         # calculate envelope for rejection sampler (eq. 4)
6669         sqrt = np.sqrt(4 * kappa ** 2. + dim_minus_one ** 2)
6670         envelop_param = (-2 * kappa + sqrt) / dim_minus_one
6671         if envelop_param == 0:
6672             # the regular formula suffers from loss of precision for high
6673             # kappa. This can only be detected by checking for 0 here.
6674             # Workaround: expansion for sqrt variable
6675             # https://www.wolframalpha.com/input?i=sqrt%284*x%5E2%2Bd%5E2%29
6676             # e = (-2 * k + sqrt(k**2 + d**2)) / d
6677             #   ~ (-2 * k + 2 * k + d**2/(4 * k) - d**4/(64 * k**3)) / d
6678             #   = d/(4 * k) - d**3/(64 * k**3)
6679             envelop_param = (dim_minus_one/4 * kappa**-1.
6680                              - dim_minus_one**3/64 * kappa**-3.)
6681         # reference step 0
6682         node = (1. - envelop_param) / (1. + envelop_param)
6683         # t = ln(1 - ((1-x)/(1+x))**2)
6684         #   = ln(4 * x / (1+x)**2)
6685         #   = ln(4) + ln(x) - 2*log1p(x)
6686         correction = (kappa * node + dim_minus_one
6687                       * (np.log(4) + np.log(envelop_param)
6688                       - 2 * np.log1p(envelop_param)))
6689         n_accepted = 0
6690         x = np.zeros((n_samples, ))
6691         halfdim = 0.5 * dim_minus_one
6692         # main loop
6693         while n_accepted < n_samples:
6694             # generate candidates acc. to reference step 1
6695             sym_beta = random_state.beta(halfdim, halfdim,
6696                                          size=n_samples - n_accepted)
6697             coord_x = (1 - (1 + envelop_param) * sym_beta) / (
6698                 1 - (1 - envelop_param) * sym_beta)
6699             # accept or reject: reference step 2
6700             # reformulation for numerical stability:
6701             # t = ln(1 - (1-x)/(1+x) * y)
6702             #   = ln((1 + x - y +x*y)/(1 +x))
6703             accept_tol = random_state.random(n_samples - n_accepted)
6704             criterion = (
6705                 kappa * coord_x
6706                 + dim_minus_one * (np.log((1 + envelop_param - coord_x
6707                 + coord_x * envelop_param) / (1 + envelop_param)))
6708                 - correction) > np.log(accept_tol)
6709             accepted_iter = np.sum(criterion)
6710             x[n_accepted:n_accepted + accepted_iter] = coord_x[criterion]
6711             n_accepted += accepted_iter
6712         # concatenate x and remaining coordinates: step 3
6713         coord_rest = _sample_uniform_direction(dim_minus_one, n_accepted,
6714                                                random_state)
6715         coord_rest = np.einsum(
6716             '...,...i->...i', np.sqrt(1 - x ** 2), coord_rest)
6717         samples = np.concatenate([x[..., None], coord_rest], axis=1)
6718         # reshape output to (size, dim)
6719         if size is not None:
6720             samples = samples.reshape(size + (dim, ))
6721         else:
6722             samples = np.squeeze(samples)
6723         return samples
6724 
6725     def _rotate_samples(self, samples, mu, dim):
6726         """A QR decomposition is used to find the rotation that maps the 
6727         north pole (1, 0,...,0) to the vector mu. This rotation is then 
6728         applied to all samples. 
6729  
6730         Parameters 
6731         ---------- 
6732         samples: array_like, shape = [..., n] 
6733         mu : array-like, shape=[n, ] 
6734             Point to parametrise the rotation. 
6735  
6736         Returns 
6737         ------- 
6738         samples : rotated samples 
6739  
6740         """
6741         base_point = np.zeros((dim, ))
6742         base_point[0] = 1.
6743         embedded = np.concatenate([mu[None, :], np.zeros((dim - 1, dim))])
6744         rotmatrix, _ = np.linalg.qr(np.transpose(embedded))
6745         if np.allclose(np.matmul(rotmatrix, base_point[:, None])[:, 0], mu):
6746             rotsign = 1
6747         else:
6748             rotsign = -1
6749 
6750         # apply rotation
6751         samples = np.einsum('ij,...j->...i', rotmatrix, samples) * rotsign
6752         return samples
6753 
6754     def _rvs(self, dim, mu, kappa, size, random_state):
6755         if dim == 2:
6756             samples = self._rvs_2d(mu, kappa, size, random_state)
6757         elif dim == 3:
6758             samples = self._rvs_3d(kappa, size, random_state)
6759         else:
6760             samples = self._rejection_sampling(dim, kappa, size,
6761                                                random_state)
6762 
6763         if dim != 2:
6764             samples = self._rotate_samples(samples, mu, dim)
6765         return samples
6766 
6767     def rvs(self, mu=None, kappa=1, size=1, random_state=None):
6768         """Draw random samples from a von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6769  
6770         Parameters 
6771         ---------- 
6772         mu : array_like 
6773             Mean direction of the distribution. Must be a one-dimensional unit 
6774             vector of norm 1. 
6775         kappa : float 
6776             Concentration parameter. Must be positive. 
6777         size : int or tuple of ints, optional 
6778             Given a shape of, for example, (m,n,k), m*n*k samples are 
6779             generated, and packed in an m-by-n-by-k arrangement. 
6780             Because each sample is N-dimensional, the output shape 
6781             is (m,n,k,N). If no shape is specified, a single (N-D) 
6782             sample is returned. 
6783         random_state : {None, int, np.random.RandomState, np.random.Generator}, 
6784                         optional 
6785             Used for drawing random variates. 
6786             If `seed` is `None`, the `~np.random.RandomState` singleton is used. 
6787             If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, seeded 
6788             with seed. 
6789             If `seed` is already a ``RandomState`` or ``Generator`` instance, 
6790             then that object is used. 
6791             Default is `None`. 
6792  
6793         Returns 
6794         ------- 
6795         rvs : ndarray 
6796             Random variates of shape (`size`, `N`), where `N` is the 
6797             dimension of the distribution. 
6798  
6799         """
6800         dim, mu, kappa = self._process_parameters(mu, kappa)
6801         random_state = self._get_random_state(random_state)
6802         samples = self._rvs(dim, mu, kappa, size, random_state)
6803         return samples
6804 
6805     def _entropy(self, dim, kappa):
6806         halfdim = 0.5 * dim
6807         return (-self._log_norm_factor(dim, kappa) - kappa *
6808                 ive(halfdim, kappa) / ive(halfdim - 1, kappa))
6809 
6810     def entropy(self, mu=None, kappa=1):
6811         """Compute the differential entropy of the von Mises-Fisher 
6812         distribution. 
6813  
6814         Parameters 
6815         ---------- 
6816         mu : array_like, default: None 
6817             Mean direction of the distribution. Must be a one-dimensional unit 
6818             vector of norm 1. 
6819         kappa : float, default: 1 
6820             Concentration parameter. Must be positive. 
6821  
6822         Returns 
6823         ------- 
6824         h : scalar 
6825             Entropy of the von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6826  
6827         """
6828         dim, _, kappa = self._process_parameters(mu, kappa)
6829         return self._entropy(dim, kappa)
6830 
6831     def fit(self, x):
6832         """Fit the von Mises-Fisher distribution to data. 
6833  
6834         Parameters 
6835         ---------- 
6836         x : array-like 
6837             Data the distribution is fitted to. Must be two dimensional. 
6838             The second axis of `x` must be unit vectors of norm 1 and 
6839             determine the dimensionality of the fitted 
6840             von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6841  
6842         Returns 
6843         ------- 
6844         mu : ndarray 
6845             Estimated mean direction. 
6846         kappa : float 
6847             Estimated concentration parameter. 
6848  
6849         """
6850         # validate input data
6851         x = np.asarray(x)
6852         if x.ndim != 2:
6853             raise ValueError("'x' must be two dimensional.")
6854         if not np.allclose(np.linalg.norm(x, axis=-1), 1.):
6855             msg = "'x' must be unit vectors of norm 1 along last dimension."
6856             raise ValueError(msg)
6857         dim = x.shape[-1]
6858 
6859         # mu is simply the directional mean
6860         dirstats = directional_stats(x)
6861         mu = dirstats.mean_direction
6862         r = dirstats.mean_resultant_length
6863 
6864         # kappa is the solution to the equation:
6865         # r = I[dim/2](kappa) / I[dim/2 -1](kappa)
6866         #   = I[dim/2](kappa) * exp(-kappa) / I[dim/2 -1](kappa) * exp(-kappa)
6867         #   = ive(dim/2, kappa) / ive(dim/2 -1, kappa)
6868 
6869         halfdim = 0.5 * dim
6870 
6871         def solve_for_kappa(kappa):
6872             bessel_vals = ive([halfdim, halfdim - 1], kappa)
6873             return bessel_vals[0]/bessel_vals[1] - r
6874 
6875         root_res = root_scalar(solve_for_kappa, method="brentq",
6876                                bracket=(1e-8, 1e9))
6877         kappa = root_res.root
6878         return mu, kappa
6879 
6880 
6881 vonmises_fisher = vonmises_fisher_gen()
6882 
6883 
6884 class vonmises_fisher_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
6885     def __init__(self, mu=None, kappa=1, seed=None):
6886         """Create a frozen von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6887  
6888         Parameters 
6889         ---------- 
6890         mu : array_like, default: None 
6891             Mean direction of the distribution. 
6892         kappa : float, default: 1 
6893             Concentration parameter. Must be positive. 
6894         seed : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, 
6895                 `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
6896             If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
6897             singleton is used. 
6898             If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
6899             seeded with `seed`. 
6900             If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance 
6901             then that instance is used. 
6902  
6903         """
6904         self._dist = vonmises_fisher_gen(seed)
6905         self.dim, self.mu, self.kappa = (
6906             self._dist._process_parameters(mu, kappa)
6907         )
6908 
6909     def logpdf(self, x):
6910         """ 
6911         Parameters 
6912         ---------- 
6913         x : array_like 
6914             Points at which to evaluate the log of the probability 
6915             density function. The last axis of `x` must correspond 
6916             to unit vectors of the same dimensionality as the distribution. 
6917  
6918         Returns 
6919         ------- 
6920         logpdf : ndarray or scalar 
6921             Log of probability density function evaluated at `x`. 
6922  
6923         """
6924         return self._dist._logpdf(x, self.dim, self.mu, self.kappa)
6925 
6926     def pdf(self, x):
6927         """ 
6928         Parameters 
6929         ---------- 
6930         x : array_like 
6931             Points at which to evaluate the log of the probability 
6932             density function. The last axis of `x` must correspond 
6933             to unit vectors of the same dimensionality as the distribution. 
6934  
6935         Returns 
6936         ------- 
6937         pdf : ndarray or scalar 
6938             Probability density function evaluated at `x`. 
6939  
6940         """
6941         return np.exp(self.logpdf(x))
6942 
6943     def rvs(self, size=1, random_state=None):
6944         """Draw random variates from the Von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6945  
6946         Parameters 
6947         ---------- 
6948         size : int or tuple of ints, optional 
6949             Given a shape of, for example, (m,n,k), m*n*k samples are 
6950             generated, and packed in an m-by-n-by-k arrangement. 
6951             Because each sample is N-dimensional, the output shape 
6952             is (m,n,k,N). If no shape is specified, a single (N-D) 
6953             sample is returned. 
6954         random_state : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`, 
6955                         `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional 
6956             If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState` 
6957             singleton is used. 
6958             If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, 
6959             seeded with `seed`. 
6960             If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance 
6961             then that instance is used. 
6962  
6963         Returns 
6964         ------- 
6965         rvs : ndarray or scalar 
6966             Random variates of size (`size`, `N`), where `N` is the 
6967             dimension of the distribution. 
6968  
6969         """
6970         random_state = self._dist._get_random_state(random_state)
6971         return self._dist._rvs(self.dim, self.mu, self.kappa, size,
6972                                random_state)
6973 
6974     def entropy(self):
6975         """ 
6976         Calculate the differential entropy of the von Mises-Fisher 
6977         distribution. 
6978  
6979         Returns 
6980         ------- 
6981         h: float 
6982             Entropy of the Von Mises-Fisher distribution. 
6983  
6984         """
6985         return self._dist._entropy(self.dim, self.kappa)

6988 class normal_inverse_gamma_gen(multi_rv_generic):
6989     r"""Normal-inverse-gamma distribution. 
6990  
6991     The normal-inverse-gamma distribution is the conjugate prior of a normal 
6992     distribution with unknown mean and variance. 
6993  
6994     Methods 
6995     ------- 
6996     pdf(x, s2, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1) 
6997         Probability density function. 
6998     logpdf(x, s2, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1) 
6999         Log of the probability density function. 
7000     mean(mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1) 
7001         Distribution mean. 
7002     var(mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1) 
7003         Distribution variance. 
7004     rvs(mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1, size=None, random_state=None) 
7005         Draw random samples. 
7006  
7007     Parameters 
7008     ---------- 
7009     mu, lmbda, a, b  : array_like 
7010         Shape parameters of the distribution. See notes. 
7011     seed : {None, int, np.random.RandomState, np.random.Generator}, optional 
7012         Used for drawing random variates. 
7013         If `seed` is `None`, the `~np.random.RandomState` singleton is used. 
7014         If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, seeded 
7015         with seed. 
7016         If `seed` is already a ``RandomState`` or ``Generator`` instance, 
7017         then that object is used. 
7018         Default is `None`. 
7019  
7020     See Also 
7021     -------- 
7022     norm 
7023     invgamma 
7024  
7025     Notes 
7026     ----- 
7027  
7028     The probability density function of `normal_inverse_gamma` is: 
7029  
7030     .. math:: 
7031  
7032         f(x, \sigma^2; \mu, \lambda, \alpha, \beta) = 
7033             \frac{\sqrt{\lambda}}{\sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^2}} 
7034             \frac{\beta^\alpha}{\Gamma(\alpha)} 
7035             \left( \frac{1}{\sigma^2} \right)^{\alpha + 1} 
7036             \exp \left(- \frac{2 \beta + \lambda (x - \mu)^2} {2 \sigma^2} \right) 
7037  
7038     where all parameters are real and finite, and :math:`\sigma^2 > 0`, 
7039     :math:`\lambda > 0`, :math:`\alpha > 0`, and :math:`\beta > 0`. 
7040  
7041     Methods ``normal_inverse_gamma.pdf`` and ``normal_inverse_gamma.logpdf`` 
7042     accept `x` and `s2` for arguments :math:`x` and :math:`\sigma^2`. 
7043     All methods accept `mu`, `lmbda`, `a`, and `b` for shape parameters 
7044     :math:`\mu`, :math:`\lambda`, :math:`\alpha`, and :math:`\beta`, 
7045     respectively. 
7046  
7047     .. versionadded:: 1.15 
7048  
7049     References 
7050     ---------- 
7051     .. [1] Normal-inverse-gamma distribution, Wikipedia, 
7052            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal-inverse-gamma_distribution 
7053  
7054     Examples 
7055     -------- 
7056     Suppose we wish to investigate the relationship between the 
7057     normal-inverse-gamma distribution and the inverse gamma distribution. 
7058  
7059     >>> import numpy as np 
7060     >>> from scipy import stats 
7061     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
7062     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng(527484872345) 
7063     >>> mu, lmbda, a, b = 0, 1, 20, 20 
7064     >>> norm_inv_gamma = stats.normal_inverse_gamma(mu, lmbda, a, b) 
7065     >>> inv_gamma = stats.invgamma(a, scale=b) 
7066  
7067     One approach is to compare the distribution of the `s2` elements of 
7068     random variates against the PDF of an inverse gamma distribution. 
7069  
7070     >>> _, s2 = norm_inv_gamma.rvs(size=10000, random_state=rng) 
7071     >>> bins = np.linspace(s2.min(), s2.max(), 50) 
7072     >>> plt.hist(s2, bins=bins, density=True, label='Frequency density') 
7073     >>> s2 = np.linspace(s2.min(), s2.max(), 300) 
7074     >>> plt.plot(s2, inv_gamma.pdf(s2), label='PDF') 
7075     >>> plt.xlabel(r'$\sigma^2$') 
7076     >>> plt.ylabel('Frequency density / PMF') 
7077     >>> plt.show() 
7078  
7079     Similarly, we can compare the marginal distribution of `s2` against 
7080     an inverse gamma distribution. 
7081  
7082     >>> from scipy.integrate import quad_vec 
7083     >>> from scipy import integrate 
7084     >>> s2 = np.linspace(0.5, 3, 6) 
7085     >>> res = quad_vec(lambda x: norm_inv_gamma.pdf(x, s2), -np.inf, np.inf)[0] 
7086     >>> np.allclose(res, inv_gamma.pdf(s2)) 
7087     True 
7088  
7089     The sample mean is comparable to the mean of the distribution. 
7090  
7091     >>> x, s2 = norm_inv_gamma.rvs(size=10000, random_state=rng) 
7092     >>> x.mean(), s2.mean() 
7093     (np.float64(-0.005254750127304425), np.float64(1.050438111436508)) 
7094     >>> norm_inv_gamma.mean() 
7095     (np.float64(0.0), np.float64(1.0526315789473684)) 
7096  
7097     Similarly, for the variance: 
7098  
7099     >>> x.var(ddof=1), s2.var(ddof=1) 
7100     (np.float64(1.0546150578185023), np.float64(0.061829865266330754)) 
7101     >>> norm_inv_gamma.var() 
7102     (np.float64(1.0526315789473684), np.float64(0.061557402277623886)) 
7103  
7104     """
7105     def rvs(self, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1, size=None, random_state=None):
7106         """Draw random samples from the distribution. 
7107  
7108         Parameters 
7109         ---------- 
7110         mu, lmbda, a, b : array_like, optional 
7111             Shape parameters. `lmbda`, `a`, and `b` must be greater 
7112             than zero. 
7113         size : int or tuple of ints, optional 
7114             Shape of samples to draw. 
7115         random_state : {None, int, np.random.RandomState, np.random.Generator}, optional 
7116             Used for drawing random variates. 
7117             If `random_state` is `None`, the `~np.random.RandomState` singleton is used. 
7118             If `random_state` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used, seeded 
7119             with `random_state`. 
7120             If `random_state` is already a ``RandomState`` or ``Generator`` instance, 
7121             then that object is used. 
7122             Default is `None`. 
7123  
7124         Returns 
7125         ------- 
7126         x, s2 : ndarray 
7127             Random variates. 
7128  
7129         """
7130         random_state = self._get_random_state(random_state)
7131         s2 = invgamma(a, scale=b).rvs(size=size, random_state=random_state)
7132         scale = (s2 / lmbda)**0.5
7133         x = norm(loc=mu, scale=scale).rvs(size=size, random_state=random_state)
7134         dtype = np.result_type(1.0, mu, lmbda, a, b)
7135         return x.astype(dtype), s2.astype(dtype)
7136 
7137     def _logpdf(self, x, s2, mu, lmbda, a, b):
7138         t1 = 0.5 * (np.log(lmbda) - np.log(2 * np.pi * s2))
7139         t2 = a*np.log(b) - special.gammaln(a).astype(a.dtype)
7140         t3 = -(a + 1) * np.log(s2)
7141         t4 = -(2*b + lmbda*(x - mu)**2) / (2*s2)
7142         return t1 + t2 + t3 + t4
7143 
7144     def logpdf(self, x, s2, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1):
7145         """Log of the probability density function. 
7146  
7147         Parameters 
7148         ---------- 
7149         x, s2 : array_like 
7150             Arguments. `s2` must be greater than zero. 
7151         mu, lmbda, a, b : array_like, optional 
7152             Shape parameters. `lmbda`, `a`, and `b` must be greater 
7153             than zero. 
7154  
7155         Returns 
7156         ------- 
7157         logpdf : ndarray or scalar 
7158             Log of the probability density function. 
7159  
7160         """
7161         invalid, args = self._process_parameters_pdf(x, s2, mu, lmbda, a, b)
7162         s2 = args[1]
7163         # Keep it simple for now; lazyselect later, perhaps.
7164         with np.errstate(all='ignore'):
7165             logpdf = np.asarray(self._logpdf(*args))
7166         logpdf[s2 <= 0] = -np.inf
7167         logpdf[invalid] = np.nan
7168         return logpdf[()]
7169 
7170     def _pdf(self, x, s2, mu, lmbda, a, b):
7171         t1 = np.sqrt(lmbda / (2 * np.pi * s2))
7172         t2 = b**a / special.gamma(a).astype(a.dtype)
7173         t3 = (1 / s2)**(a + 1)
7174         t4 = np.exp(-(2*b + lmbda*(x - mu)**2) / (2*s2))
7175         return t1 * t2 * t3 * t4
7176 
7177     def pdf(self, x, s2, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1):
7178         """The probability density function. 
7179  
7180         Parameters 
7181         ---------- 
7182         x, s2 : array_like 
7183             Arguments. `s2` must be greater than zero. 
7184         mu, lmbda, a, b : array_like, optional 
7185             Shape parameters. `lmbda`, `a`, and `b` must be greater 
7186             than zero. 
7187  
7188         Returns 
7189         ------- 
7190         logpdf : ndarray or scalar 
7191             The probability density function. 
7192  
7193         """
7194         invalid, args = self._process_parameters_pdf(x, s2, mu, lmbda, a, b)
7195         s2 = args[1]
7196         # Keep it simple for now; lazyselect later, perhaps.
7197         with np.errstate(all='ignore'):
7198             pdf = np.asarray(self._pdf(*args))
7199         pdf[s2 <= 0] = 0
7200         pdf[invalid] = np.nan
7201         return pdf[()]
7202 
7203     def mean(self, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1):
7204         """The mean of the distribution. 
7205  
7206         Parameters 
7207         ---------- 
7208         mu, lmbda, a, b : array_like, optional 
7209             Shape parameters. `lmbda` and `b` must be greater 
7210             than zero, and `a` must be greater than one. 
7211  
7212         Returns 
7213         ------- 
7214         x, s2 : ndarray 
7215             The mean of the distribution. 
7216  
7217         """
7218         invalid, args = self._process_shapes(mu, lmbda, a, b)
7219         mu, lmbda, a, b = args
7220         invalid |= ~(a > 1)
7221         mean_x = np.asarray(mu).copy()
7222         mean_s2 = np.asarray(b / (a - 1))
7223         mean_x[invalid] = np.nan
7224         mean_s2[invalid] = np.nan
7225         return mean_x[()], mean_s2[()]
7226 
7227     def var(self, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1):
7228         """The variance of the distribution. 
7229  
7230         Parameters 
7231         ---------- 
7232         mu, lmbda, a, b : array_like, optional 
7233             Shape parameters. `lmbda` and `b` must be greater 
7234             than zero, and `a` must be greater than two. 
7235  
7236         Returns 
7237         ------- 
7238         x, s2 : ndarray 
7239             The variance of the distribution. 
7240  
7241         """
7242         invalid, args = self._process_shapes(mu, lmbda, a, b)
7243         mu, lmbda, a, b = args
7244         invalid_x = invalid | ~(a > 1)
7245         invalid_s2 = invalid | ~(a > 2)
7246         var_x = b / ((a - 1) * lmbda)
7247         var_s2 = b**2 / ((a - 1)**2 * (a - 2))
7248         var_x, var_s2 = np.asarray(var_x), np.asarray(var_s2)
7249         var_x[invalid_x] = np.nan
7250         var_s2[invalid_s2] = np.nan
7251         return var_x[()], var_s2[()]
7252 
7253     def _process_parameters_pdf(self, x, s2, mu, lmbda, a, b):
7254         args = np.broadcast_arrays(x, s2, mu, lmbda, a, b)
7255         dtype = np.result_type(1.0, *(arg.dtype for arg in args))
7256         args = [arg.astype(dtype, copy=False) for arg in args]
7257         x, s2, mu, lmbda, a, b = args
7258         invalid = ~((lmbda > 0) & (a > 0) & (b > 0))
7259         return invalid, args
7260 
7261     def _process_shapes(self, mu, lmbda, a, b):
7262         args = np.broadcast_arrays(mu, lmbda, a, b)
7263         dtype = np.result_type(1.0, *(arg.dtype for arg in args))
7264         args = [arg.astype(dtype, copy=False) for arg in args]
7265         mu, lmbda, a, b = args
7266         invalid = ~((lmbda > 0) & (a > 0) & (b > 0))
7267         return invalid, args
7268 
7269     def __call__(self, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1, seed=None):
7270         return normal_inverse_gamma_frozen(mu, lmbda, a, b, seed=seed)
7271 
7272 
7273 normal_inverse_gamma = normal_inverse_gamma_gen()
7274 
7275 
7276 class normal_inverse_gamma_frozen(multi_rv_frozen):
7277 
7278     def __init__(self, mu=0, lmbda=1, a=1, b=1, seed=None):
7279         self._dist = normal_inverse_gamma_gen(seed)
7280         self._shapes = mu, lmbda, a, b
7281 
7282     def logpdf(self, x, s2):
7283         return self._dist.logpdf(x, s2, *self._shapes)
7284 
7285     def pdf(self, x, s2):
7286         return self._dist.pdf(x, s2, *self._shapes)
7287 
7288     def mean(self):
7289         return self._dist.mean(*self._shapes)
7290 
7291     def var(self):
7292         return self._dist.var(*self._shapes)
7293 
7294     def rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
7295         return self._dist.rvs(*self._shapes, size=size, random_state=random_state)

7298 # Set frozen generator docstrings from corresponding docstrings in
7299 # normal_inverse_gamma_gen and fill in default strings in class docstrings
7300 for name in ['logpdf', 'pdf', 'mean', 'var', 'rvs']:
7301     method = normal_inverse_gamma_gen.__dict__[name]
7302     method_frozen = normal_inverse_gamma_frozen.__dict__[name]
7303     method_frozen.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(method.__doc__,
7304                                              mvn_docdict_noparams)
7305     method.__doc__ = doccer.docformat(method.__doc__, mvn_docdict_params)
